{{Other uses}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | image1 = Sade (van Loo) flip.png | width1 = 223 | caption1 = [[Marquis de Sade]] | image2 = Jacob Huysmans - Portrait of John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester 1.jpg | width2 = 175 | caption2 = [[John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester|John Wilmot]] }} A '''libertine''' is one devoid of most moral principles, a sense of responsibility, or [[Human sexual activity|sexual]] restraints, which are seen as unnecessary or undesirable, especially one who ignores or even spurns accepted morals and forms of behaviour sanctified by the larger society.<ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/libertine "Libertine" at the Free Dictionary]</ref><ref>[http://wordnetweb.princeton.edu/perl/webwn?s=libertine "libertine"] at [[WordNet]]</ref> Libertinism is described as an extreme form of [[hedonism]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=vSU2xOR7a4oC&pg=PA54&lpg=PA54&dq=libertine+extreme+hedonist&source=bl&ots=wwH1ILqrbO&sig=B07mMtdciiO_aOVrTVpEY7zb8u0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjf6Ku2vbLKAhXESCYKHfoxDrcQ6AEISjAJ#v=onepage&q=libertine%20extreme%20hedonist&f=false The Origins of Jewish Secularization in 18th Century Europe by Schmuel Feiner]</ref> Libertines put value on physical pleasures, meaning those experienced through the senses. As a philosophy, libertinism gained new-found adherents in the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries, particularly in [[France]] and [[Great Britain]]. Notable among these were [[John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester]] and the [[Marquis de Sade]].
== History of the term == {{Individualism sidebar}} The word "Libertine" was originally coined by [[John Calvin]] to negatively describe opponents of his policies in Geneva, Switzerland.<ref>{{cite EB1911 |wstitle=Libertines |volume=16 |page=543 |first=Alexander |last=Gordon}}</ref> This group, led by [[Ami Perrin]], argued against Calvin's "insistence that church discipline should be enforced uniformly against all members of Genevan society".<ref name=zophy>{{cite book |last=Zophy |first=Johnathan W. |title=A Short History of Renaissance and Reformation Europe: Dances Over Fire and Water |edition=Third |publisher=Prentice Hall |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-13-097764-9 |page=226 }}</ref> Perrin and his allies were elected to the town council in 1548, and "broadened their support base in [[Geneva]] by stirring up resentment among the older inhabitants against the increasing number of religious refugees who were fleeing France in even greater numbers".<ref name=zophy /> By 1555, [[Calvinist]]s were firmly in place on the Genevan town council, so the Libertines, led by Perrin, responded with an "attempted coup against the government and called for the massacre of the French. This was the last great political challenge Calvin had to face in Geneva".<ref name=zophy />
During the 18th and 19th centuries, the term became more associated with debauchery.<ref>{{cite book |editor=Michel Delon |authorlink= |title=Encyclopedia of the Enlightenment |year=2013 |publisher=Routledge |location= |pages=2362–2363 |quote= |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=rElJAgAAQBAJ |page=2363 }} |isbn=978-1-135-96005-6 }}</ref> [[Charles-Maurice de Talleyrand]] wrote that [[Joseph Bonaparte]] "sought only life's pleasures and easy access to libertinism" while on the throne of Naples.<ref>{{cite book |first=Charles-Maurice de |last=Talleyrand |chapter=Napoleon's European Legacy, 1853 |title=Napoleon: Symbol for an Age, A Brief History with Documents |editor-first=Rafe |editor-last=Blaufarb |location=New York |publisher=Bedford/St. Martin's |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-312-43110-5 |page=151 }}</ref>
== Literature ==
''[[Les Liaisons dangereuses]]'' (''Dangerous Liaisons'', 1782), an [[epistolary novel]] by [[Pierre Choderlos de Laclos]], is a trenchant description of sexual libertinism. [[Wayland Young]] argues: {{quote|...the mere analysis of libertinism... carried out by a novelist with such a prodigious command of his medium... was enough to condemn it and play a large part in its destruction.<ref>{{cite book | last=Young | first=Wayland | title=Eros Denied | publisher=Grove | year=1966 | location=New York }}</ref>}}
Agreeable to Calvin's emphasis on the need for uniformity of discipline in Geneva, [[Samuel Rutherford]] (Professor of Divinity in the University of St. Andrews, and Christian minister in 17th Century Scotland) offered a rigorous treatment of "Libertinism" in his polemical work "A Free Disputation against pretended Liberty of Conscience" (1649).
''[[A Satyr Against Reason and Mankind]]'' is a poem by John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester which addresses the question of the proper use of [[reason]], and is generally assumed to be a [[Hobbesian]] critique of [[rationalism]].<ref name=Fisher>{{cite journal |last=Fisher |first=Nicholas |title=The Contemporary Reception of Rochester's A Satyr against Mankind |journal=[[The Review of English Studies]] |year=2006 |volume=57 |issue=229 |pages=185–220 |doi=10.1093/res/hgl035 }}</ref> The narrator subordinates reason to sense.<ref name="Jenkinson101">{{cite book|last=Jenkinson|first=Matthew|title=Culture and Politics at the Court of Charles II, 1660–1685 |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=8-sGu6QN_CcC |page=99 }} |year=2010|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|isbn=978-1-84383-590-5|page=101}}</ref> It is based to some extent on [[Nicolas Boileau-Despréaux|Boileau]]'s version of [[Juvenal]]'s eighth or fifteenth satire, and is also indebted to Hobbes, [[Montaigne]], [[Lucretius]] and [[Epicurus]], as well as the general libertine tradition.<ref name="Jenkinson2010" /> Confusion has arisen in its interpretation as it is ambiguous as to whether the speaker is Rochester himself, or a satirised persona.<ref name="Thormählen1993">{{cite book |last=Thormählen |first=Marianne |title=Rochester |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=cxLBy2XR_H0C |page=190 }} |accessdate=4 April 2013 |date=25 June 1993 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-44042-4 |page=191 }}</ref> It criticises the vanities and corruptions of the statesmen and politicians of the court of Charles II.<ref name="Jenkinson2010">{{cite book|last=Jenkinson|first=Matthew|title=Culture and Politics at the Court of Charles II: 1660–1685 |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=8-sGu6QN_CcC |page=99 }} |accessdate=4 April 2013|year=2010|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|isbn=978-1-84383-590-5|page=99}}</ref>
The [[libertine novel]] was an [[18th century in literature|18th century literary genre]] of which the roots lay in the European but mainly French libertine tradition. The genre effectively ended with the [[French Revolution]]. Themes of libertine novels were [[anti-clericalism]], [[anti-establishment]] and [[erotic literature|eroticism]].
Authors include [[Claude Prosper Jolyot de Crébillon]] (''[[Les Égarements du cœur et de l'esprit]]'', 1736; ''[[Le Sopha, conte moral]]'', 1742), [[Denis Diderot]] (''[[Les bijoux indiscrets]]'', 1748), [[Marquis de Sade]] (''[[L'Histoire de Juliette]]'', 1797–1801), [[Choderlos de Laclos]] (''[[Les Liaisons dangereuses]]'', 1782), [[John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester|John Wilmot]] (''[[Sodom, or the Quintessence of Debauchery]]'', 1684).
Other famous titles are ''[[Histoire de Dom Bougre, Portier des Chartreux]]'' (1741) and ''[[Thérèse Philosophe]]'' (1748).
Precursors to the libertine writers were [[Théophile de Viau]] (1590–1626) and [[Charles de Saint-Evremond]] (1610–1703), who were inspired by [[Epicurus]] and the publication of [[Petronius]].
[[Robert Darnton]] is a cultural historian who has covered this genre extensively.
Critics have been divided as to the literary merits of [[William Hazlitt]]'s ''Liber Amoris'', a deeply personal account of frustrated [[Lolita]]-like love that is quite unlike anything else Hazlitt ever wrote. Wardle suggests that it was compelling but marred by sickly sentimentality, and also proposes that Hazlitt might even have been anticipating some of the experiments in chronology made by later novelists.<ref>Wardle, pp. 363–65. Wardle was writing in 1971; twenty-first-century critics continue to be sharply divided. David Armitage has assessed the book disparagingly as "the result of a tormented mind grasping literary motifs in a desperate and increasingly unsuccessful (and self indulgent) attempt to communicate its descent into incoherence...", while Gregory Dart has acclaimed it "the most powerful account of unrequited love in English literature". To James Ley, "It is ... an unsparing account of the psychology of obsession, the way a mind in the grip of an all-consuming passion can distort reality to its own detriment". Armitage, p. 223; Dart 2012, p. 85; Ley p. 38.</ref>
One or two positive reviews appeared, such as the one in the ''Globe'', 7 June 1823: "The ''Liber Amoris'' is unique in the English language; and as, possibly, the first book in its fervour, its vehemency, and its careless exposure of passion and weakness—of sentiments and sensations which the common race of mankind seek most studiously to mystify or conceal—that exhibits a portion of the most distinguishing characteristics of Rousseau, it ought to be generally praised".<ref>Quoted by Jones, p. 338.</ref> [[Dan Cruickshank]] in his book ''London's Sinful Secret'' summarized Hazlitt's infatuation stating: "Decades after her death Batsy (Careless) still haunted the imagination of the essayist William Hazlitt, a man who lodged near Covent Garden during the 1820s, where he became unpleasantly intimate with the social consequences of unconventional sexual obsession that he revealed in his ''Liber Amoris'' of 1823, in which he candidly confessed to his infatuation with his landlord's young daughter."<ref>[[Dan Cruickshank]], ''London's Sinful Secret'', p.92. St. Martin's Press, New York (2009).</ref>
== Philosophy == During the [[Baroque era]] in France, there existed a [[Freethought|freethinking]] circle of philosophers and intellectuals who were collectively known as ''libertinage érudit'' and which included [[Gabriel Naudé]], [[Élie Diodati]] and [[François de La Mothe Le Vayer]].<ref>{{cite book |author=René Pintard |title=Le Libertinage érudit dans la première moitié du XVIIe siècle |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=IeL29wMqdbgC |page=11 }} |accessdate=24 July 2012 |year=2000 |publisher=Slatkine |isbn=978-2-05-101818-0 |page=11 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/fideism/ |title=Fideism |website=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy |accessdate= }}</ref> The critic [[Vivian de Sola Pinto]] linked [[John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester]]'s libertinism to [[Hobbesian]] [[materialism]].<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/00/02/20/specials/greene-monkey.html |title=A Martyr to Sin |date=September 15, 1974 |newspaper=[[New York Times]] }}</ref>
== Notable libertines == {{refimprove|section|date=November 2016}} Some notable libertines include:

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}}
'''Michael Peinovich''' (born 1977),<ref name="SPLC">{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/individual/michael-enoch-peinovich |title=Michael "Enoch" Peinovich | Southern Poverty Law Center |publisher=Splcenter.org |date= |accessdate=July 11, 2018}}</ref> commonly known by his pseudonym '''Mike Enoch''', is an American [[white nationalist]]{{r|SPLC}} and [[Neo-Nazi]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Brian Lisi |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/neo-nazi-blog-struggles-founder-wife-identified-jewish-article-1.2948308 |title=Neo-Nazi blog struggles after founder's wife is revealed to be Jewish |publisher=NY Daily News |date=January 17, 2017 |accessdate=July 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Friedman |first=Dan |url=https://forward.com/fast-forward/360054/does-neo-nazi-media-kingpin-live-on-upper-east-side-with-a-jewish-wife/ |title=Neo-Nazi Rivals Claim Their Media Kingpin Lives on Upper East Side With His Jewish Wife – The Forward |publisher=Forward.com |date=January 15, 2017 |accessdate=July 11, 2018}}</ref> [[Antisemitic canard|anti-semitic conspiracy theorist]], blogger and [[podcast]] host. He founded the alt-right media hub ''[[The Right Stuff (blog)|The Right Stuff]]'' and podcast ''The Daily Shoah''. Through his work, Peinovich ridicules African Americans and other racial minorities, advocates racial separation and a revival of explicit racial discrimination (of the sort practiced in the Jim Crow South and Nazi Germany), and promotes conspiracy theories such as [[Holocaust denial]] and [[White genocide conspiracy theory|white genocide]].
== Early life==
Peinovich grew up in suburban Pennsylvania, in an upper-middle class family; he was raised by his father, a college professor, and his stepmother.<ref name="newyorker1">{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/10/16/birth-of-a-white-supremacist |title=Birth of a White Supremacist |publisher=The New Yorker |date= |accessdate=July 11, 2018}}</ref> His parents divorced at a young age. He is of Serbian and Norwegian descent. After graduating high school, he attended and dropped out of several universities before being hired as a computer programmer.{{Cn|date=July 2018}}
Peinovich's father has disowned him and asked him to change his surname, in light of his neo-Nazi political activities as "Mike Enoch."<ref name="newyorker1"/>
==''The Right Stuff''== {{main|The Right Stuff (blog)}} '''The Right Stuff''' is a [[white nationalism|white nationalist]], [[Neo-Nazism|Neo-Nazi]] blog founded by Enoch that hosts several podcasts, including ''The Daily [[Shoah]].'' The blog is best known for popularizing the use of [[Triple parentheses|"echoes"]], an antisemitic marker which uses triple parentheses around names used to identify [[Jews]] and people of the [[Judaism|Jewish faith]] on social media.<ref name="mic">{{cite web|author= |url=https://mic.com/articles/144228/echoes-exposed-the-secret-symbol-neo-nazis-use-to-target-jews-online#.7LAtTw8df |title=(((Echoes))), Exposed: The Secret Symbol Neo-Nazis Use to Target Jews Online |website=Mic.com |date=June 1, 2016 |accessdate=September 25, 2016}}</ref><ref name="teenvogue">{{cite web|author=Joshua Eaton |url=http://www.teenvogue.com/story/neo-nazi-groups-target-jewish-people-social-media-echoes-symbol |title=Secret Neo-Nazi Message on Social Media: (((Echoes))) - Anti-Semitism |publisher=Teen Vogue |date=June 6, 2016 |accessdate=September 25, 2016}}</ref><ref name="smh">{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/web-culture/antisemitic-chrome-extension-highlighted-jews-for-attack-online-20160606-gpd1i7.html|title=Anti-Zionist Chrome extension highlighted Jews for attack online|last=|first=|date=|website=|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |access-date=September 25, 2016}}</ref> It is part of the broader [[alt-right]] movement in the United States.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/founder-neo-nazi-blog-quits-after-he-was-revealed-have-jewish-wife-1601480|title=Founder of Neo-Nazi blog quits after he was revealed to have Jewish wife|last=Palmer|first=Ewan|date=January 17, 2017|newspaper=International Business Times UK|access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/16/politics/white-nationalists-trump-losing-faith/index.html|title=How white nationalists are losing faith in Trump|last=CNN|first=Sara Ganim and Chris Welch|website=CNN|access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref>
''The Right Stuff'' was one of the first websites to make use of the term "[[cuckservative]]", long before the epithet attracted mainstream attention.<ref name="doifeelcuckypunk">{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2015/08/07/getting-cucky-brief-primer-radical-right%E2%80%99s-newest-%E2%80%98cuckservative%E2%80%99-meme |title=Getting Cucky: A Brief Primer On The Radical Right's Newest 'Cuckservative' Meme | Southern Poverty Law Center |website=Splcenter.org |date=August 7, 2015 |accessdate=September 25, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Weigel|first1=David|title='Cuckservative' — the conservative insult of the month, explained|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2015/07/29/cuckservative-the-conservative-insult-of-the-month-explained/|accessdate=June 10, 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=July 29, 2015}}</ref> The [[Anti-Defamation League]] notes that ''The Right Stuff'', like other similar organizations including [[Identity Evropa]] and [[Vanguard America]], has also coalesced into a network of regional groups to coordinate activities in the real world, such as posting fliers promoting "white heritage" in various cities and universities in the United States.<ref name="adl._AltR">{{cite web | title = Alt Right Moving From Online to Real-World Activity | author = | work = Anti-Defamation League | date = February 13, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = https://www.adl.org/blog/alt-right-moving-from-online-to-real-world-activity | quote = During the fall of 2016 up until the present, people associated with alt right groups such as Identity Evropa, American Vanguard and The Right Stuff (TRS) have been posting fliers that promote "white heritage" at campuses around the country. TRS is a website but some of its followers have cohered into something like a real-world group.}}</ref>
===''The Daily Shoah''=== First broadcast in August 2014 and published weekly (and now three times every week),<ref name=ep1>{{Cite episode|title=The Daily Shoah! Episode 1|url=https://radio.therightstuff.biz/2014/08/03/the-daily-shoah-episode-1/|access-date=August 28, 2016|series=The Daily Shoah|first=|last=Seventh Son|network=The Right Stuff Radio|station=|date=August 3, 2014|season=|series-no=|number=|minutes=|time=|transcript=|transcript-url=|quote=|language=English|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160919150612/https://radio.therightstuff.biz/2014/08/03/the-daily-shoah-episode-1/|archivedate=September 19, 2016}}</ref> ''The Daily Shoah'''s name is a parody of ''[[The Daily Show]]'' and uses the [[Hebrew language]] word referring to [[the Holocaust]].<ref name="daily">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/11/arts/for-the-alt-right-the-message-is-in-the-punctuation.html?_r=0|title=For the Alt-Right, the Message Is in the Punctuation|work=The New York Times}}</ref> Enoch originally created the show to be edgy and [[Libertarianism in the United States|libertarian]], and later began sharing [[Antisemitic conspiracy theories|antisemitic conspiracy theories]] around Episode 19, after reading ''[[The Culture of Critique series|The Culture of Critique]]'' by [[Kevin B. MacDonald]].<ref name=sortashoah /><ref name=rebelshoah>{{cite web | title = Rebel Shoah 20170118 Fashy Struggle Session | author = Musonius Rufus | work = SoundCloud | date = January 18, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = https://soundcloud.com/musonius-rufus/rebel-shoah-20170118-fashy-struggle-session | quote = }}</ref>{{primary inline|date=November 2017}}
On the show Enoch, along with co-host Seventh Son and a rotating panel of co-hosts and guests (known as "the Death Panel") has addressed topics such as [[Immigration in the United States|immigration]], [[white nationalism]], [[Race relations in the United States|race relations]], [[Feminism in the United States|feminism]], [[Zionism]], [[Anti-globalization movement|anti-globalization]] and [[political correctness]].<ref name=aboutus>{{cite web |url=http://therightstuff.biz/about-us/ |title=About Us |author= |date= |website= |publisher=The Right Stuff |access-date=August 28, 2016 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160830061426/http://therightstuff.biz/about-us/ |archivedate=August 30, 2016 }}</ref>
The podcast is widely credited with creating the [[triple parentheses]] meme, also known as (((echo))), an [[antisemitism|antisemitic]] symbol that has been used to highlight the names of individuals of Jewish ethnicity.<ref name=micEcho>{{cite news |last1=Fleishman |first1=Cooper |last2=Smith |first2=Anthony |date=June 1, 2016 |title=(((Echoes))), Exposed: The Secret Symbol Neo-Nazis Use to Target Jews Online |url=https://mic.com/articles/144228/echoes-exposed-the-secret-symbol-neo-nazis-use-to-target-jews-online |newspaper=[[Mic.com]] |location= |access-date=August 28, 2016 }}</ref><ref name=adlEcho>{{cite web |url=http://www.adl.org/combating-hate/hate-on-display/c/echo.html |title=Echo |author=Anti-Defamation League |date= |website= |publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]] |access-date=August 28, 2016 |quote=}}</ref><ref name=micEchoHate>{{cite news |last1=Fleishman |first1=Cooper |last2=Smith |first2=Anthony |date=June 6, 2016 |title=The Neo-Nazi (((Echoes))) Symbol Is Officially Hate Speech |url=https://mic.com/articles/145459/the-neo-nazi-echoes-symbol-is-officially-hate-speech |newspaper=[[Mic.com]] |location= |access-date=August 28, 2016 }}</ref>
{{As of|January 2017}}, ''The Daily Shoah'' reportedly had an audience of 100,000 listeners.<ref name=ibtimesdox />
==Doxing incident== In January 2017, users of the [[imageboard]] website [[8chan]] leaked the identities of several of its key contributors, including Peinovich, and revealed that his wife was of Jewish ancestry.<ref name=salondox0>{{cite web|last=Sheffield|first=Matthew|title=The alt-right eats its own: Neo-Nazi podcaster "Mike Enoch" quits after doxxers reveal his wife is Jewish|url=http://www.salon.com/2017/01/16/cat-fight-on-the-alt-right-neo-nazi-podcaster-mike-enoch-quits-after-doxxers-reveal-his-wife-is-jewish/|website=Salon}}</ref><ref name=toidox>{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/white-supremacist-outed-for-having-jewish-wife/|title=White supremacist outed for having Jewish wife|newspaper=The Times of Israel|language=en-US|access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref> Other information released included the names of his family members, his job as a software developer, home address on [[Manhattan]]'s [[Upper East Side]] neighborhood, and his hometown of [[Maplewood, New Jersey]].<ref name="forw_Raci">{{cite web | title = Racist Rivals Claim Neo-Nazi Media Kingpin Lives on Upper East Side With His Jewish Wife | author = Dan Friedman | work = The Forward | date = January 15, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = http://forward.com/fast-forward/360054/does-neo-nazi-media-kingpin-live-on-upper-east-side-with-a-jewish-wife/ | language = | quote = }}</ref> After initially attempting to deny the reports, Peinovich later admitted that the allegations were true.<ref name=ibtimesdox>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/founder-neo-nazi-blog-quits-after-he-was-revealed-have-jewish-wife-1601480|title=Founder of Neo-Nazi blog quits after he was revealed to have Jewish wife|last=Palmer|first=Ewan|date=January 17, 2017|newspaper=International Business Times UK|access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref> Though Peinovich initially planned to leave the network, he quickly changed his mind and vowed to continue his activities.<ref name=salondox1>{{cite web|title = Disgraced Neo-Nazi pundit "Mike Enoch" vows to expand racist podcast network, despite alt-right doxxing war| last = Sheffield | first = Matthew| work = Salon| date = | accessdate = May 1, 2017| url = http://www.salon.com/2017/01/19/disgraced-neo-nazi-pundit-mike-enoch-vows-to-expand-racist-podcast-network-despite-alt-right-doxxing-war/| language = English}}</ref>
In an audio statement released on their podcast, ''Daily Shoah'' co-host Seventh Son announced that Peinovich and his wife were separating.<ref name=salondox1 /><ref name=sortashoah>{{cite web |url=http://therightstuff.biz/2017/01/17/the-sorta-shoah-122/ |title=The Sorta Shoah |author=Seventh Son |date=January 17, 2017 |website=The Right Stuff |access-date=January 17, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118044612/http://therightstuff.biz/2017/01/17/the-sorta-shoah-122/ |archivedate=January 18, 2017 }}</ref> The revelation was met with mixed but mostly supportive reactions from fellow alt-right leaders, including [[David Duke]],<ref name=dailynewsdox>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/neo-nazi-blog-struggles-founder-wife-identified-jewish-article-1.2948308|title=Neo-Nazi blog struggles after founder's wife identified as Jewish|newspaper=NY Daily News|access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref> and [[Richard B. Spencer]].<ref name=salondox1 />
==Political activities==
After [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Congressman]] [[Steve King]] tweeted praise for Netherlands [[Parliamentary group leader|political candidate]] [[Geert Wilders]]'s strong stance against [[Opposition to immigration#Europe|further immigration to Europe]], Peinovich joined other alt-right voices in approval of King's position, stating "King doubles down. Great job. Take note cucks, this is how you *actually* fight the left."<ref name="adl._Whit">{{cite web | title = White Supremacists Praise Rep. Steve King's Racist Tweet | author = | work = Anti-Defamation League | date = March 15, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = https://www.adl.org/blog/white-supremacists-praise-rep-steve-kings-racist-tweet | quote = }}</ref>
He had expressed support for [[Donald Trump]] during the presidential election and the first months of his term, but has disavowed him after Donald Trump ordered airstrikes in Syria. On March 9, Enoch took part in an [[anti-war movement|anti-war protest]] opposing the [[2017 Shayrat missile strike]], in which 59 [[Tomahawk (missile)|Tomahawk]] [[Cruise missile]]s were launched by the United States against the [[Shayrat Airbase]] controlled by [[Bashar al-Assad]] and his forces.<ref name="altr_Anti">{{cite web | title = Antifa Protest Alt-Right For Protesting Trump's Syrian Intervention | last = Wallace | first = Hunter | work = AltRight.com | date = April 9, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = https://altright.com/2017/04/09/antifa-protest-alt-right-for-protesting-trumps-syrian-intervention/ | quote = }}</ref> The protest, organized by [[Richard B. Spencer]], was counter-protested by anti-fascist activists.<ref name="altr_Anti" /> On the next episode of ''The Daily Shoah'', Enoch and Spencer railed against the perceived attitudes of mainstream conservatives, especially [[Baby Boomer]]s, and spoke about the growing (and, in their opinions, undue) influence of [[Ivanka Trump]] and [[Senior Advisor to the President of the United States|Senior Adviser]] [[Jared Kushner]] on President [[Donald Trump]],<ref name="nyti_Jare">{{cite news | title = Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump: Pillars of Family-Driven West Wing | last = Baker | first = Peter | last2 = Thrush | first2 = Glenn | last3 = Haberman | first3 = Maggie | work = nytimes.com | date = April 15, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/15/us/politics/jared-kushner-ivanka-trump-white-house.html | quote = }}</ref><ref name="poli_Kush">{{cite web | title = Kushner's privileged status stokes resentment in White House | last = Dawsey | first = Josh | last2 = Vogel | first2 = Kenneth P. | last3 = Isenstadt | first3 = Alex | work = POLITICO | date = April 1, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/jared-kushner-white-house-influence-236758 | language = | quote = }}</ref> as well as [[Neoconservativism|neoconservative]] and pro-Israel influences within the Trump administration.<ref name=soldiersofforeskin>{{cite web | title = THE DAILY SHOAH #146: Soldiers of Foreskin | author = Seventh Son | work = radio.therightstuff.biz | date = April 11, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = https://radio.therightstuff.biz/2017/04/11/the-daily-shoah-146-soldiers-of-foreskin/ | quote = | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170719213141/https://radio.therightstuff.biz/2017/04/11/the-daily-shoah-146-soldiers-of-foreskin/ | archivedate = July 19, 2017 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> He also commented that the alt-right was now "the only legitimate anti-war movement in the United States," and that the antifa counter-protesters supported Trump and the military strike by virtue of counter-protesting an anti-war demonstration.<ref name=soldiersofforeskin />
On April 18, 2017, Enoch joined Richard B. Spencer in giving a talk at [[Auburn University]] where he expressed that he and the movement were breaking away from the new direction that the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]] was taking.<ref name=newrepublic>{{cite web | title = The Alt-Right and Donald Trump Get a Divorce | author = | work = New Republic | date = April 26, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = https://newrepublic.com/article/142276/alt-right-donald-trump-get-divorce | quote = }}</ref> While Auburn administration had initially cancelled the planned event, citing safety concerns, Enoch assisted Spencer in filing a lawsuit on [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] grounds.<ref name=newrepublic/> [[United States federal judge]] [[William Keith Watkins]] issued a ruling requiring Auburn to allow Spencer and Enoch to speak.<ref name=auburnwapo>{{cite web | title = Federal judge stops Auburn from canceling white nationalist Richard Spencer speech. Protests and a scuffle greet him. | author = Travis M. Andrews | work = Washington Post | date = April 19, 2017 | accessdate = May 1, 2017 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/04/19/federal-judge-stops-auburn-from-canceling-white-nationalists-speech-violence-erupts/ | quote = On Tuesday, U.S. District Judge W. Keith Watkins in Montgomery, Ala., Tuesday barred Auburn from blocking Spencer, stating there was no evidence that he advocates violence. "Discrimination on the basis of message content cannot be tolerated under the First Amendment," he wrote in the ruling. }}</ref>
==Social media== In April 2018, he was [[retweet]]ed by [[Ann Coulter]]. After ''[[Newsweek]]'' reached out to [[Twitter]] asking for a comment, his [[Twitter suspensions|account was suspended]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/ann-coulter-trump-white-nationalist-887699 |newspaper=[[Newsweek]] |title=Ann Coulter retweets White Nationalist Charlotesville Leader who attacked Trump with Syria Conspiracy Theory |author=Michael Edison Hayden |date=April 16, 2018}}</ref>

In mathematics, a '''monotonically normal space''' is a particular kind of [[normal space]], with some special characteristics, and is such that it is hereditarily normal, and any two separated subsets are strongly separated. They are defined in terms of a monotone normality operator.
A <math>T_1</math> [[topological space]] <math>(X,\mathcal T)</math> is said to be ''monotonically normal'' if the following condition holds:
For every <math>x\in G</math>, where G is open, there is an open set <math>\mu(x,G)</math> such that #<math>x\in\mu(x,G)\subseteq G</math> #if <math>\mu(x,G)\cap\mu(y,H)\neq\emptyset</math> then either <math>x\in H</math> or <math>y\in G</math>.
There are some equivalent criteria of monotone normality.
==Equivalent definitions== ===Definition 2===
A space X is called monotonically normal if it is <math>T_1</math> and for each pair of disjoint closed subsets <math>A,B</math> there is an open set <math>G(A,B)</math> with the properties
# <math>A\subseteq G(A,B)\subseteq G(A,B)^{-}\subseteq X\backslash B</math> and # <math>G(A,B)\subseteq G(A',B')</math>, whenever <math>A \subseteq A'</math> and <math>B ' \subseteq B</math>.
This operator <math>G</math> is called '''monotone normality operator'''.
Note that if G is a monotone normality operator, then <math>\tilde G</math> defined by <math>\tilde G(A,B)=G(A,B)\backslash G(B,A)^{-}</math> is also a monotone normality operator; and <math>\tilde G</math> satisfies :<math>\begin{align} \tilde G(A,B)\cap \tilde G(B,A)=\emptyset \end{align}</math>
For this reason we some time take the monotone normality operator so as to satisfy the above requirement; and that facilitates the proof of some theorems and of the equivalence of the definitions as well.
===Definition 3===
A space X is called monotonically normal if it is <math>T_1</math>,and to each pair (A, B) of subsets of X, with <math>A\cap B^{-}=\emptyset=B\cap A^{-}</math>, one can assign an open subset G(A, B) of X such that # <math>A \subseteq G ( A , B) \subseteq G ( A , B)^{-}\subseteq X\backslash B,</math> # <math>G(A, B) \subseteq G(A', B') \mbox{ whenever }A \subseteq A' \mbox{ and } B'\subseteq B</math>.
===Definition 4===
A space X is called monotonically normal if it is <math>T_1</math> and there is a function H that assigns to each ordered pair (p,C) where C is closed and p is without C, an open set H(p,C) satisfying: # <math>p\in H(p,C)\subseteq X\backslash C</math> # if D is closed and <math>p\not\in C\supseteq D</math> then <math>H(p,C)\subseteq H(p,D)</math> # if <math>p\neq q</math> are points in X, then <math>H(p,\{q\})\cap H(q,\{p\})=\emptyset</math>.
==Properties== An important example of these spaces would be, assuming Axiom of Choice, the linearly ordered spaces; however, it really needs [[axiom of choice]] for an arbitrary linear order to be [[normal space|normal]] (see van Douwen's paper). Any [[generalised metric]] is monotonically normal even without choice. An important property of monotonically normal spaces is that any two separated subsets are strongly separated there. Monotone normality is hereditary property and a monotonically normal space is always normal by the first condition of the second equivalent definition.
We list up some of the properties : # A [[closed map]] preserves monotone normality. # A monotonically normal space is hereditarily [[collectionwise normal]]. # Elastic spaces are monotonically normal.

[[Music]] has been used in [[psychological operations]]. The term '''music torture''' is sometimes used by critics of the practice of playing [[loud music]] incessantly to prisoners or people besieged. The [[United Nations]] and the [[European Court of Human Rights]] have banned the use of loud music in [[interrogation]]s.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} The term [[torture]] is sometimes used to describe the practice. While it is acknowledged by US interrogation experts that it causes discomfort, it has also been characterized by them as causing no "long-term effects". {{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3042907.stm | title=Sesame Street breaks Iraqi POWs | publisher=[[BBC]] | date=May 23, 2003 | accessdate=2007-11-27 }} Music and sound have been usually used as part of a combination of interrogation methods, today recognized by international bodies as amounting to torture.UN Committee Against Torture 1997 "Concluding observations: Israel. 09/05/1997." {{cite web |url=http://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/1B3ED23212DCBE3B05256547005C47FA |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728224401/http://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/1B3ED23212DCBE3B05256547005C47FA |archivedate=2014-07-28 |df= }} Attacking all senses without leaving any visible traces, they have formed the basis of the widely discussed torture in [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp|Guantanamo]] and [[Abu Ghraib prison|Abu Ghraib]]. They were, however, devised much earlier in the 1950s and early 1960s, as a way to counter so-called Soviet "brainwashing".McCoy, Alfred W (2006). ''A Question of Torture. CIA Interrogation. From the Cold War to the War on Terror''. New York: Henry Holt and Co.pp. They include: * sensory deprivation * stress positions * sleep deprivation * food and drink deprivation * continuous music or sound ==Instances of use== === [[United States]] === * A BBC News report claimed that music by the American [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[Metallica]] and children's [[TV]] programs ''[[Barney the Dinosaur|Barney]]'' and ''[[Sesame Street]]'', was used for [[sleep deprivation]] and to culturally offend Iraqi [[POWs]]. {{cite news | url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/59300/output/print | title=Periscope | author=[[A.L. Bardach]], [[Jac Chebatoris]] | publisher=[[Newsweek]] | date=May 19, 2003 | accessdate=2007-11-27 }} {{cite news | url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/59409 | title=The Love's not mutual | publisher=[[Newsweek]] | date=May 26, 2003 | accessdate=2007-11-27 }} * Claimed to being used by the [[United States]] [[361st Psychological Operations Company]] by Sergeant [[Mark Hadsell]]: {{quotation| "These people haven't heard heavy metal. They can't take it. If you play it for 24 hours, your brain and body functions start to slide, your train of thought slows down and your will is broken. That's when we come in and talk to them."}} * In the [[War on Terror]], the US used songs "[[The Real Slim Shady]]", the [[Meow Mix#Jingles|Meow Mix theme song]], and "Fuck Your God" by Deicide to torture.{{cite web |url=https://mic.com/articles/87851/11-popular-songs-the-cia-used-to-torture-prisoners-in-the-war-on-terror |title=11 Popular Songs the CIA Used to Torture Prisoners in the War on Terror |author=Tom Barnes |date=April 22, 2014}} * "When the [[United States invaded Panama]] in December 1989, Noriega took refuge in the [[Holy See]]’s embassy on December 24, which was immediately surrounded by U.S. troops. After being continually bombarded by [[hard rock]] music, including [[Van Halen|Van Halen's]] hit song [[Panama (song)|''Panama'']],[http://ivarfjeld.wordpress.com/2010/04/30/when-heavy-rock-was-used-to-get-general-noriega-out-of-vatican-protection/] and ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'' for several days, Noriega surrendered on January 3, 1990." {{cite news | url=http://kanga.tamucc.edu/PublicAffairs/press/2007/september/cisneros.html | title=Ret. Lt. Gen. Marc Cisneros to Discuss Capture of Former Panamanian Dictator with A&M-Corpus Christi Students | publisher=[[Texas A&M University]] | date=September 19, 2007 | accessdate=2007-11-27 }}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} {{cite news |url=http://www.dtic.mil/doctrine/jel/jfq_pubs/1220.pdf |title=Grenada, Panama, and Haiti: Joint Operational Reform |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] |author=[[Ronald H. Cole]] |date=Winter 1998–1999 |accessdate=2007-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111211070618/http://www.dtic.mil/doctrine/jel/jfq_pubs/1220.pdf |archivedate=2011-12-11 |df= }} * According to the FBI: {{cite news | url=http://foia.fbi.gov/guantanamo/122106.htm | title=Guantanamo Bay Inquiry (released under FOIA) | publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] | accessdate=2007-11-27 }} {{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A14936-2004Dec20?language=printer | title=FBI Agents Allege Abuse of Detainees at Guantanamo Bay | pages=Page A01 | publisher=[[Washington Post]] | author=[[Dan Eggen]], [[R. Jeffrey Smith]] | date=December 21, 2004 | accessdate=2007-11-27 }}
"W[itness] observed sleep deprivation interviews w/strobe lights and loud music. Interrogator said it would take 4 days to break someone doing an interrogation 16 hrs w/lights and music on and 4 hrs off. Handwritten note next to typed synopsis says "ok under DoD policy". "Rumors that interrogator bragged about doing lap dance on d[etainee], another about making d[etainee] listen to satanic [[black metal]] music for hours then dressing as a Priest and baptizing d[etainee] to save him - handwritten note says 'yes'." "W[itness] saw d[etainee] in interview room sitting on floor w/Israeli flag draped around him, loud music and strobe lights. W suspects this practice is used by DOD DHS based on who he saw in the hallway."
* The ''[[Washington Post]]'', quoting a leaked Red Cross report, wrote: {{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A21262-2004Nov30.html | title=Red Cross Cites 'Inhumane' Treatment at Guantanamo | pages=Page A10 | publisher=[[Washington Post]] | author=[[Josh White (journalist)|Josh White]], John Mintz | date=December 1, 2004 | accessdate=2007-11-27 }}
"The physical tactics noted by the [[Red Cross]] included placing detainees in extremely cold rooms with loud music blaring, and forcing them to kneel for long periods of time, the source familiar with the report said."
* ''[[The Hill (newspaper)]]'', reporting on the #OccupyLafayettePark protests, wrote: {{cite news |url = http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/397813-former-clinton-adviser-hires-mariachi-band-to-play-at-anti-trump |title = Former Clinton adviser hires mariachi band to play at anti-Trump protests outside White House |publisher = [[The Hill(newspaper)]] |date = July 19, 2018 |accessdate=2018-07-19 |author = Morgan Gstalter }}
"A former adviser to Hillary Clinton hired a Mariachi band to play outside of the White House in an effort to disrupt President Trump's sleep on Wednesday night."
=== [[Iraq]] === According to [[Amnesty International]]: {{cite news |url = https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/mde14/017/2004/en/ |title = Iraq: Torture not isolated -- independent investigations vital |publisher = [[Amnesty International]] |date = April 30, 2004 |accessdate = 2007-11-27 |df = }} "Detainees have reported being routinely subjected to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment during arrest and detention. Many have told Amnesty International that they were tortured and ill-treated by US and UK troops during interrogation. Methods often reported include prolonged sleep deprivation; beatings; prolonged restraint in painful positions, sometimes combined with exposure to loud music; prolonged hooding; and exposure to bright lights. Virtually none of the allegations of torture or ill-treatment has been adequately investigated by the authorities." === [[Israel]] === On January 12, 1998 the [[Supreme Court of Israel]] declined to ban the use of loud music as an interrogation technique. {{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-60847881.html | title=Israel refuses to ban loud music torture | publisher=[[Birminghan Post]] | author=[[Gwen Ackerman]] | date=January 12, 1998 | accessdate=2007-11-27 }} === [[Greece]] === According to recent research, the [[Greek military junta of 1967–74|Greek military Junta]] (1967–1974) used the above-mentioned combination of interrogation techniques, including music. This took place in the headquarters of the Special Interrogation Unit of Greek Military Police (EAT/ESA), Athens. New interviews with survivors, held there in 1973, talk about the use of songs, popular hits of the time: these were played loudly and repeatedly from loudspeakers as the detainee had to stand without rest, food, drink or sleep.Papaeti Anna (2013). “Music, Torture, Testimony: Reopening the Case of the Greek Military Junta (1967–74).” the world of music (special issue): Music and Torture | Music and Punishment 2:1(2013), guest edited by M. J. Grant and Anna Papaeti, pp. 73–80. ==Popular culture== In the book ''[[A Clockwork Orange (novel)|A Clockwork Orange]]'' by [[Anthony Burgess]] and the subsequent [[A Clockwork Orange (film)|film]] based upon it, a rebellious teenager is subjected to brutal experimental brain-washing techniques that cause him to feel physical pain if he has similar violent thoughts to those that sent him to jail in the first place; as an accidental side-effect, he has the same response if he hears [[Beethoven's Ninth Symphony]]. Later, a man tortures him by locking him in a room where the symphony is played loudly. In ''[[Back to the Future]]'', Marty used music made by [[Van Halen]] to scare his dad, George McFly, awake, implying that since that kind of music did not exist in that time, it would scare him. In ''[[Apocalypse Now]]'', a helicopter squadron plays classical music, [[Richard Wagner]]'s ''[[Ride of the Valkyries]]'', over loudspeakers on-board their helicopters while attacking a Viet Cong village, as a form of psychological warfare. In [[Woody Allen]]'s early film ''[[Bananas (film)|Bananas]]'', a prisoner is tortured by being tied up in a room while operetta, featuring an annoying coluratora soprano, is played over and over on a cheap record-player. In ''[[The Drew Carey Show]]'', Mimi played "[[Panama (song)|Panama]]" by Van Halen repeatedly to drive Drew and friends from his house. In an episode of the U.S. television show ''[[Burn Notice]]'' Sam Axe plays loud music to a prisoner to break his will. In the film ''[[The Men Who Stare at Goats (film)|The Men Who Stare at Goats]]'', a take-off of the [[Barney & Friends]] ending song "I Love You" is played in the cells of Iraqi detainees as a form of torture. In the TV series ''[[Homeland (TV series)|Homeland]]'', [[Grindcore]] is used to keep a prisoner awake. In ''Power Rangers Megaforce'', Emma sings a song to help the rangers defeat Dischord. In the series 'Lost', [[drum and bass]] music is used to keep an islander's boyfriend awake and indoctrinated and tortured. In one episode of 'The Flash' Cisco plays 'Never Gonna Give You Up' on repeat to Hartley get him to reveal information they need. Public awareness of the use of this technique is widespread enough that it can be used in satirical attacks on popular culture: {{quotation|"Hollywood — Several days after Paris Hilton announced that she will release a music album, the Pentagon has decided to buy 50,000 copies of her upcoming album to use against insurgents in the volatile Anbar province in western Iraq."{{cite news|url=http://datelinehollywood.com/archives/2006/06/12/us-military-to-attack-insurgents-with-paris-hilton-album/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20060615002213/http://datelinehollywood.com/archives/2006/06/12/us-military-to-attack-insurgents-with-paris-hilton-album/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-06-15 |title=U.S. MILITARY TO ATTACK INSURGENTS WITH PARIS HILTON ALBUM |publisher=[[Dateline Hollywood]] |author= |date= |accessdate=2007-11-27 }}}} In the TV series ''[[American Horror Story]]'', in the second season titled ''[[American Horror Story: Asylum|Asylum]]'', the song "[[Dominique]]" is played constantly for the asylum patients in the episode "[[Welcome to Briarcliff]]". In the TV series "[[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]]", the song "Easy Street" by "The Collapsable Hearts Club" is played repeatedly to [[Daryl Dixon]] in order to torture him. In [[Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy (film)]] a captured British intelligence officer under interrogation in a Soviet prison is subjected to disturbing sounds being repeatedly played through a pair of headphones ==Royalty payments== ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that the US military may owe royalty payments to the artists whose works were played to the captives. {{cite news |url=http://www.lightreading.com/blog.asp?blog_sectionid=222&doc_id=159515 |title=Gitmo's Greatest Hits |publisher=[[Light Reading]] |author= |date=2008-07-21 |accessdate=2008-07-21 |quote= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519022424/http://www.lightreading.com/blog.asp?blog_sectionid=222&doc_id=159515 |archivedate=2011-05-19 |df= }} {{cite news |url=http://music.guardian.co.uk/news/story/0,,2289778,00.html |title=Music as torture may incur royalty fees |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |author=[[Sean Michaels (writer)|Sean Michaels]] |date=2008-07-09 |accessdate=2008-07-21 |quote= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ZUEut33Y?url=http://music.guardian.co.uk/news/story/0,,2289778,00.html |archivedate=2008-07-21 |df= }} ==Musicians' protests== On 9 December 2008 the ''[[Associated Press]]'' reported that various musicians were coordinating their objections to the use of their music as a technique for softening up captives through an initiative called Zero dB.{{cite web | url=http://www.zerodb.org/ | title=Zero dB web site | accessdate=2009-10-29 }} {{cite news |url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g64EuoVhuWIkenJw0OsqodF-EbnwD94VDHPG0 |title = Musicians protest use of songs by US jailers |publisher = [[Associated Press]] |author = [[Andrew Selsky]] |date = 2008-12-09 |accessdate = 2008-12-09 |quote = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081212095349/http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g64EuoVhuWIkenJw0OsqodF-EbnwD94VDHPG0 |archivedate = 2008-12-12 |df = }} Zero dB is an initiative against music torture set up by legal charity [[Reprieve (organisation)|Reprieve]], which represents over thirty prisoners in Guantanamo Bay. Zero dB aims to stop torture music by encouraging widespread condemnation of the practice and by calling on governments and the UN to uphold and enforce the Convention Against Torture and other relevant treaties. The initiative is backed by the Musicians Union which is calling on British musicians to voice their outrage against the use of music to torture. Musicians and the wider public are making their own silent protests against music torture which are being shown on Zero dB. A series of silent protests and actions are planned through 2009. Participating musicians will include minutes of silence in their concerts to draw their audience's attention to the USA's use of deafening music against captives. According to the ''Associated Press'' [[FBI]] agents stationed at Guantanamo Bay reported that the use of deafening music was common. According to the ''Associated Press'' Guantanamo Bay spokesmen [[Commander]] [[Pauline Storum]]: :{| class="wikitable" border="1" | :''"...wouldn't give details of when and how music has been used at the prison, but said it isn't used today. She didn't respond when asked whether music might be used in the future." |} Among the musicians united in their objections were [[Christopher Cerf (musician and television producer)|Christopher Cerf]], a composer for the children's show [[Sesame Street]], and [[Tom Morello]] of [[Rage Against the Machine]] and [[Audioslave]]. Others include [[Massive Attack]],[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rGS5o4KoOCk You Tube video] [[R.E.M.]], [[The Roots]], [[Rise Against]], [[Rosanne Cash]], [[Pearl Jam]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], [[Trent Reznor]], [[Billy Bragg]], [[Michelle Branch]], [[Jackson Browne]], [[T-Bone Burnett]], [[David Byrne]], [[Marc Cohn]], [[Steve Earle]], [[Limp Bizkit]], [[System of a Down]], [[Disturbed (band)|Disturbed]], [[the Entrance Band]], [[Skinny Puppy]]https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/feb/07/skinny-puppy-payment-guantanamo and [[Joe Henry]]. {{cite web |url = http://newsecurityaction.org/pages/music-used-to-torture |title = Musicians Standing Against Torture |publisher = New Security Action |accessdate = 2009-10-29 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091026114058/http://www.newsecurityaction.org/pages/music-used-to-torture |archivedate = 2009-10-26 |df = }} The ''Associated Press'' reported that [[Stevie Benton]] of the group [[Drowning Pool]] commented: :{| class="wikitable" border="1" | :''"I take it as an honor to think that perhaps our song could be used to quell another 9/11 attack or something like that." |} On December 13, 2008, Benton issued an apology on the band's MySpace page about his comment on musical torture, stating his comment had been "taken out of context".{{cite web |url=http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendID=4989818&blogID=456111734 |title=Drowning Pool official MySpace blog (Stevie Bentons Apology) |publisher=Blogs.myspace.com |date=December 14, 2008 |accessdate=October 21, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207065936/http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view |archivedate=February 7, 2009 |df= }} ==See also== * [[Psychological torture]] * [[Loud music]] * ''[[High Anxiety]]'' * [[Music and political warfare]] * [[Gitmo playlist]] * [[Psychic driving]] * [[Acoustic harassment]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} == Further reading == * [[Moustafa Bayoumi]]. 'Disco Inferno.' ''The Nation'' December 7, 2005. Available at http://www.thenation.com/doc/20051226/bayoumi. * [[Suzanne Cusick|Cusick, Suzanne]]. 'You are in a place that is out of the world . . .': Music in the Detention Camps of the 'Global War on Terror'. ''Journal of the Society for American Music'' 2/1 (2008): 1-26. * Cusick, Suzanne. 'Music as torture / Music as weapon.' ''Revista Transcultural de Música/Transcultural Music Review'' 10 (2006). Available at https://web.archive.org/web/20070207092801/http://www.sibetrans.com/trans/trans10/cusick_eng.htm. * {{cite news |url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hJwF0o-W0CViiBuvIAepcXZc7l1QD94VDI7G0 |title = Songs forced on detainees by US jailers |publisher = [[Associated Press]] |author = |date = 2008-12-08 |accessdate = 2008-12-20 |quote = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081219225605/http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hJwF0o-W0CViiBuvIAepcXZc7l1QD94VDI7G0 |archivedate = 2008-12-19 |df = }} * {{cite news |url=http://www.alternet.org/rights/113479/a_history_of_music_torture_in_the_war_on_terror_/?comments=view&cID=1084926&pID=1084880 |title=A History of Music Torture in the War on Terror |publisher=[[CounterPunch]] |author=[[Andy Worthington]] |date=2008-12-17 |accessdate=2008-09-28 |quote= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604201817/http://www.alternet.org/rights/113479/a_history_of_music_torture_in_the_war_on_terror_/?comments=view&cID=1084926&pID=1084880 |archivedate=2011-06-04 |df= }} * {{cite news |url=http://www.motherjones.com/news/feature/2008/03/am-i-a-torturer.html |title=Am I a Torturer? |publisher=[[Mother Jones magazine]] |author=Justine Sharrock |date=March–April 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-15 |quote= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5drAHbYsq?url=http://www.motherjones.com/news/feature/2008/03/am-i-a-torturer.html |archivedate=2009-01-15 |df= }} * M. J. Grant and Anna Papaeti (guest editors), ''the world of music (new series): Music and Torture | Music and Punishment'' vol. 2 no. 1 (2013). * Anna Papaeti and M. J. Grant (guest editors), ''Torture: Journal on Rehabilitation of Torture Victims and Prevention of Torture: Special Thematic Issue ‘Music in Detention’'' vol. 23 no.2 (2013). http://www.irct.org/media-and-resources/library/torture-journal/archive/volume-23--no.-2--2013.aspx * [[Jon Ronson]]. ''[[The Men Who Stare at Goats]]''. [[New York City|New York]]: [[Simon & Schuster]], 2004. {{About|the definition of necessity according to [[criminal law]]|the concept of necessity in [[tort]]|Necessity (tort)|the concept of necessity in [[international law]]|Military necessity|concept of necessity in [[constitutional law]]|Doctrine of necessity|logical meanings|Necessary (disambiguation)|and|Modal logic}} {{Criminal defenses}}
In the [[criminal law]] of many nations, '''necessity''' may be either a possible [[Justification (jurisprudence)|justification]] or an exculpation for breaking the [[law]]. [[Defendant]]s seeking to rely on this [[defense (legal)|defense]] argue that they should not be held [[liable]] for their [[action (philosophy)|actions]] as a [[crime]] because their conduct was ''necessary'' to prevent some greater harm and when that conduct is not excused under some other more specific provision of law such as [[self defense]]. Except for a few statutory exemptions and in some medical cases<ref>See Re A (Conjoined Twins: Surgical Separation) [2001] Fam 147</ref> there is no corresponding defense in [[Necessity in English law#History|English law]] for murder.<ref>See [[R v Dudley and Stephens]] [1884] 14 QBD 273 and R v Howe [1987] 1 AC 417</ref>
For example, a drunk driver might contend that he drove his car to get away from a [[kidnap]] (cf. ''[[North by Northwest#Plot|North by Northwest]]''). Most [[common law]] and [[civil law (legal system)|civil law]] [[jurisdiction]]s recognize this defense, but only under limited circumstances. Generally, the defendant must affirmatively show (i.e., introduce some evidence) that (a) the harm he sought to avoid outweighs the danger of the prohibited conduct he is charged with; (b) he had no reasonable alternative; (c) he ceased to engage in the prohibited conduct as soon as the danger passed; and (d) he did not himself create the danger he sought to avoid. Thus, with the "drunk driver" example cited above, the necessity defense will not be recognized if the defendant drove further than was reasonably necessary to get away from the kidnapper, or if some other reasonable alternative was available to him.
==General discussion== As a matter of political expediency, states usually allow some classes of person to be excused from liability when they are engaged in socially useful functions but intentionally cause injury, loss or damage. For example, the [[fire service]]s and other [[civil defence]] [[organization]]s have a general duty to keep the [[community]] safe from harm. If a fire or flood is threatening to spread out of control, it may be reasonably necessary to destroy other property to form a [[fire break]], or to trespass on land to throw up mounds of earth to prevent the water from spreading. These examples have the common feature of individuals intentionally breaking the law because they believe it to be urgently necessary to protect others from harm, but some states distinguish between a response to a crisis arising from an entirely natural cause (an inanimate force of nature), e.g. a fire from a lightning strike or rain from a storm, and a response to an entirely human crisis. Thus, [[parent]]s who lack the financial means to feed their [[child]]ren cannot use necessity as a defense if they steal food. The existence of welfare benefits and strategies other than self-help defeat the claim of an urgent necessity that cannot be avoided in any way other than by breaking the law. Further, some states apply a test of proportionality. So the defense would only be allowed where the degree of harm actually caused was a reasonably proportionate response to the degree of harm threatened. This is a legal form of [[cost–benefit analysis]].
==Specific jurisdictions== *[[Necessity in English law|England]] *[[Necessity in Canadian law|Canada]] *[[Necessity in International law|International]]
===Denmark and Norway=== Emergency law/right (''nødret'', ''nødrett'') is the equivalent of necessity in Denmark and Norway.<ref>[https://www.retsinformation.dk/Forms/R0710.aspx?id=113401 Straffeloven] på [[Retsinformation]]</ref><ref>[http://www.lovdata.no/all/hl-20050520-028.html#17 Straffeloven av 2005 § 17]</ref> It is considered related to but separate from self-defence. Common legal examples of necessity includes: breaking windows and other objects in order to escape a fire, commandeering a vehicle to serve as an emergency ambulance, ignoring traffic rules while rushing a dying patient to a hospital, and even killing a person who poses an immediate threat to several other people not including yourself. In the last case self-defense laws are not enough, but the case is covered by ''nødret''. ''Nødret'' can only be invoked though when no other option is available.
===International law===
====Customary international law==== Under international law, an obligation of [[customary international law]] or an obligation granted under a bilateral investment treaty may be suspended under the doctrine of necessity. It is "an exception from illegality and in certain cases even as an exception from responsibility." ''See Continental Casualty Company v Argentine Republic, ICSID Case No ARB/03/09.'' In order to invoke the doctrine of necessity: (1) The invoking State must not have contributed to the state of necessity, (2) Actions taken were the only way to safeguard an essential interest from grave and impending danger. ''Id. at page 72, paragraph 165.''
===Taiwan, Republic of China=== Necessity is a possible defense per the Criminal Code<ref>[http://law.moj.gov.tw/Eng/LawClass/LawSearchNo.aspx?PC=C0000001&DF=&SNo=24 Article 24 of the Criminal Code of the Republic of China].</ref> and the Administrative Penalty Act.<ref>[http://law.moj.gov.tw/Eng/LawClass/LawSearchNo.aspx?PC=A0030210&DF=&SNo=13 Article 13 of Administrative Penalty Act].</ref>
===United States=== Necessity as a defense to criminal acts conducted to meet political ends was rejected in the case of ''United States v. Schoon''.<ref>{{citation|title=The demise of the political necessity defense: indirect civil disobedience and United States v. Schoon|year=1993|author=Cavallaro, James L., Jr.|publisher=University of California Press|issn=0008-1221}}</ref> In that case, 30 people, including appellants, gained admittance to the [[Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] office in Tucson, where they chanted "keep America's tax dollars out of El Salvador," splashed simulated blood on the counters, walls, and carpeting, and generally obstructed the office's operation. The court ruled that the elements of necessity did not exist in this case.<ref>{{cite court|litigants=U.S. v. Schoon|reporter=F2d|vol=939|opinion=826|date=July 29, 1991|url=http://openjurist.org/939/f2d/826/united-states-v-d-schoon}}</ref>
====In specific states==== * [[Necessity defense (Kansas)|Kansas]] * [[Necessity defense (New York)|New York]]
===Singapore=== Necessity is a defence per the Penal Code<ref>[http://statutes.agc.gov.sg/aol/search/display/view.w3p;ident=85fe891c-9489-47a0-a0c2-15a8a9fb92c9;page=0;query=DocId%3A%22025e7646-947b-462c-b557-60aa55dc7b42%22%20Status%3Ainforce%20Depth%3A0;rec=0#pr81-he-. Section 81 of the Penal Code of Singapore.]</ref>. This requires lack of criminal intent, good faith (due care and attention<ref>[http://statutes.agc.gov.sg/aol/search/display/view.w3p;ident=4933180d-0e2b-4808-bcb8-1e276b9522b4;page=0;query=DocId%3A%22025e7646-947b-462c-b557-60aa55dc7b42%22%20Status%3Ainforce%20Depth%3A0;rec=0#pr52-he-. Section 52 of the Penal Code of Singapore.]</ref>), and the goal of preventing harm. The harm must be sufficiently serious and imminent to justify or excuse the act.
==Canada==
In Canada, Necessity is recognized as a defence for crimes committed in urgent situations of clear and imminent peril in which the accused has no safe or legal way out of the situation.
Three Requirements for defence of necessity: (1) Urgent situation of imminent peril or danger (2) No reasonable legal alternative (3) Proportionality between harm inflicted and harm avoided
It should also be noted that the first and second element are evaluated on the modified objective standard. The third element is evaluated on a purely objective standard. [[R v Latimer]], 2001 SCC 1
== In religious law == In Judaism, the principle of ''[[pikuach nefesh]]'' allows any law to be broken to save a life, except laws against murder, adultery/incest and idolatry.
==See also== *[[Competing harms]] *[[Opinio juris sive necessitatis]]
==References== *Christie, ''The Defense of Necessity Considered from the Legal and Moral Points of View'', (1999) Vol. 48 Duke Law Journal, 975. *Fuller, Lon L. ''The Case of the Speluncean Explorers'', (1949) Vol. 62, No. 4 Harvard Law Review [http://www.nullapoena.de/stud/explorers.html ] and ''The Case of the Speluncean Explorers: A Fiftieth Anniversary Symposium'', (1999) 12 Harvard Law Review 1834. *Herman, ''United States v. Oakland Cannabis Buyer's Cooperative. Whatever Happened to Federalism?'' (2002) Vol. 95, No. 1 The Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology, 121. *Travis, M. ''The Compulsion Element in a Defence of Necessity'' (2000) [https://web.archive.org/web/20040718053121/http://homepages.ihug.co.nz/~ttpbst/me/writing/compulsion.htm] <references/>
