{{pp-semi-indef}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{good article}} {{Infobox religious building |image=Park51Rendition.jpg |caption=Artist's rendering of the originally proposed Park51 |building_name=Park51 |location= 45–51 Park Place, [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] 10007, United States{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/05/22/2010-05-22_keep_your_faith_sez_wtc_imam_tells_followers_to_stay_calm.html |author1=Kate Nocera |author2=Samuel Goldsmith |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Imam building Islamic center near Ground Zero urges worshipers to fight against backlash with peace |work=Daily News |location=New York |date=May 22, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607041747/http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/05/22/2010-05-22_keep_your_faith_sez_wtc_imam_tells_followers_to_stay_calm.html |archivedate=June 7, 2010 |df= }}{{ccite news|url=http://sify.com/news/cordoba-house-mosque-coming-up-near-ground-zero-renamed-as-park-51-news-international-khopadcajbd.html |title=Cordoba House mosque coming up near Ground Zero renamed as Park51|publisher=Sify|date=July 14, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010}} |geo = {{Coord|40|42|49|N|74|00|36|W|region:US-NY_type:landmark|display=inline}} |leadership = [[Feisal Abdul Rauf]]
[[Sharif El-Gamal]] |website= {{url|park51.org}} |architect= |architecture_type= |architecture_style= |religious_affiliation=Islam{{cite web|url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/mosque911a.htm |title=Conflict over the proposed Cordoba community center in New York Center |publisher=Religioustolerance.org |accessdate=April 26, 2013}}| functional_status = Planned; {{convert|100000|sqft}} |general_contractor = |facade_direction = |groundbreaking = 2011 (temporary mosque) |year_completed = |construction_cost = $100 million |capacity= Over 2,000 |dome_quantity= |minaret_quantity= |height_max = 13 stories |materials = Glass and steel }} {{Planned World Trade Center}} '''Park51''' (originally named '''Cordoba House''') is a development that was originally envisioned as a 13-story [[Islamic]] [[community center]] and [[mosque]] in [[Lower Manhattan]]. The developers hoped to promote an [[interfaith dialog]]ue within the greater community. Due to its proposed location two blocks from the [[World Trade Center site]], it was widely and controversially referred to as the "'''Ground Zero mosque'''".{{cite news|last1=Zraick|first1=Karen|last2=Dobnik|first2=Verena|title=Ground zero mosque opened to public Wednesday|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Latest-News-Wires/2011/0922/Ground-zero-mosque-opened-to-public-Wednesday|accessdate=19 December 2015|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Christian Science Monitor|date=September 22, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151221130220/http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Latest-News-Wires/2011/0922/Ground-zero-mosque-opened-to-public-Wednesday|archivedate=21 December 2015|df=}} The project would replace an existing 1850s building of [[Italianate architecture|Italianate style]] that was damaged in the [[September 11 attacks]]. The original design was by [[Michel Abboud]], principal of SOMA Architects, who wrestled for months with the challenge of making the building fit naturally into its lower Manhattan surroundings: on the one hand, it should have a contemporary design, and, at the same time, it should look Islamic. His design included a 500-seat auditorium, theater, [[performing arts center]], [[fitness center]], swimming pool, basketball court, childcare area, bookstore, [[culinary school]], art studio, food court, and memorial to the victims of the September 11 attacks. It also included a prayer space for the Muslim community, which would accommodate 1,000–2,000 people. In late September 2011, a temporary {{convert|4000|sqft|sqm|adj=on}} Islamic center opened in renovated space at the Park51 location. In summer 2014, it was announced that there would instead be a 3-story museum with a prayer space, as well as condos, at 49-51 Park Place. The plans were changed again in September 2015, when the owner announced a {{convert|667|ft|m|adj=on}}, 70-story luxury condominium building at the site. In May 2016, financing was secured for a 43-story condominium building with room for an Islamic cultural museum. {{TOC limit|3}} ==Background== Plans to build then-named Cordoba House were reported in ''[[The New York Times]]'' in December 2009,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/09/nyregion/09mosque.html?_r=1&sq=mosque%20ground%20zero&st=nyt&scp=1&pagewanted=all|title=Muslim Prayers and Renewal Near Ground Zero|author=Blumenthal, Ralph|date=December 9, 2009|accessdate=August 23, 2010|work=The New York Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121125062214/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/09/nyregion/09mosque.html?_r=1&sq=mosque%20ground%20zero&st=nyt&scp=1&pagewanted=all|archivedate=November 25, 2012|df=}} at a location that was already in use for Muslim worship. Early response to the project was not pronounced, and one libertarian commentator provided positive coverage.{{cite news |author=Bobby Ghosh |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,2011798,00.html |title=Mosque Controversy: Does America Have a Muslim Problem? |work=Time |date=August 19, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913145327/http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,2011798,00.html |archivedate=September 13, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|title=Anderson Cooper 360 Degrees: Firestorm Grows Over Islamic Center Near Ground Zero|author=Randi Kaye|publisher=CNN|date=August 17, 2010|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1008/17/acd.01.html|accessdate=August 26, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820024353/http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1008/17/acd.01.html|archivedate=August 20, 2010|df=}}{{cite news|author=[[Cathy Young]]|url=http://reason.com/archives/2010/08/23/a-reality-check-in-the-ground|title=A Reality Check in the Ground Zero Mosque Debate: The war of words has become short on facts|work=Reason|date=August 23, 2010|accessdate=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828101931/http://reason.com/archives/2010/08/23/a-reality-check-in-the-ground/|archivedate=August 28, 2010|df=}} The plans were reviewed by the local community board in May 2010, at which time they attracted some national media attention. Protests were sparked by a campaign launched by conservative{{cite news |title=In flap over mosque near Ground Zero, conservative bloggers gaining influence |author=Michelle Boorstein |work=The Washington Post |date=August 19, 2010 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/18/AR2010081802582.html |accessdate=September 2, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101007003057/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/18/AR2010081802582.html |archivedate=October 7, 2010 |df= }} bloggers [[Pamela Geller]] and [[Robert Spencer (author)|Robert Spencer]], founders of the group [[Stop Islamization of America]], who dubbed the project the "Ground Zero mosque",{{cite news|url=http://www.observer.com/2010/politics/creator-anti-ground-zero-mosque-bus-ads-speaks|title=The Woman Behind The Anti-Ground Zero Mosque Bus Ads|author=David Freedlander|work=The New York Observer|date=August 11, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820124032/http://www.observer.com/2010/politics/creator-anti-ground-zero-mosque-bus-ads-speaks|archivedate=August 20, 2010|df=}} and a national controversy ensued.{{cite book|url=http://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=23704|title=Making Moderate Islam: Sufism, Service, and the "Ground Zero Mosque" Controversy|last1=Corbett|first1=Rosemary R.|date=2016|publisher=Stanford University Press|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161029043841/http://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=23704|archivedate=2016-10-29|df=}} Cordoba House enlisted the public relations services of The TASC Group to help mitigate the media attention throughout the controversy.{{cite news|url=http://www.odwyerpr.com/video/092910video-islamic-center-today-show.html|title=ISLAMIC CENTER DEVELOPER ON 'TODAY'|author=Greg Hazley|work=O'Dwyer's|date=September 29, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827051648/http://www.odwyerpr.com/video/092910video-islamic-center-today-show.html|archivedate=August 27, 2017|df=}}{{cite news|url=http://www.prweek.com/article/1279068/affluent-untapped|title=Affluent and untapped|author=Tanya Lewis|work=PR Week|date=June 1, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827045808/http://www.prweek.com/article/1279068/affluent-untapped|archivedate=August 27, 2017|df=}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thetascgroup.com/featured_item/park51-the-ground-zero-mosque|title=Public Relations, Crisis Communications for PARK51 (THE "GROUND ZERO MOSQUE")|author=Larry Kopp|work=The TASC Group|date=June 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827085600/http://www.thetascgroup.com/featured_item/park51-the-ground-zero-mosque/|archivedate=August 27, 2017|df=}} Some opponents have said that the building itself would serve as a "victory memorial" to Islam. {{cite news |title=Why This Mosque on This Spot? |author=Rush Limbaugh |url=http://www.rushlimbaugh.com/home/daily/site_081710/content/01125111.guest.html |work=The Rush Limbaugh Show |date=August 17, 2010 |accessdate=September 19, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820020856/http://www.rushlimbaugh.com/home/daily/site_081710/content/01125111.guest.html |archivedate=August 20, 2010 |df= }} {{cite news |title=Pro-Victory Mosque Candlelight Vigil |author=Pamela Geller |url=http://atlasshrugs2000.typepad.com/atlas_shrugs/2010/09/pro-victory-mosque-vigil.html |work=Atlas Shrugged |date=September 11, 2010 |accessdate=September 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919163512/http://atlasshrugs2000.typepad.com/atlas_shrugs/2010/09/pro-victory-mosque-vigil.html |archivedate=September 19, 2010 |df= }} Supporters have said that arguments against the building are based on the notion that Islam, rather than [[Islamic radicalism|Islamic radicals]], is responsible for the terrorist attack. The ''New York Times'' reported that Muslim religious facilities previously existed at the World Trade Center itself before the attacks.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/11/nyregion/11religion.html|title=Muslims and Islam Were Part of Twin Towers' Life|author=Samuel G. Fredman|date=September 10, 2010|work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111227091806/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/11/nyregion/11religion.html|archivedate=December 27, 2011|df=}} Opponents have also argued that the project should not be built because polls have shown that most Americans, including most residents of New York State and New York City (though not most residents of Manhattan),{{cite web|url=http://maristpoll.marist.edu/wp-content/misc/nycpolls/c100728/Bloomberg_RV/Complete%20August%2010,%202010%20NYC%20Poll%20Release%20and%20Tables.pdf|title=Bloomberg's Approval Rating: Voters' Views on Mosque Near Ground Zero: Bloomberg's Legacy|publisher=[[Marist Poll]]|date=August 10, 2010|accessdate=August 30, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100816135902/http://maristpoll.marist.edu/wp-content/misc/nycpolls/c100728/Bloomberg_RV/Complete%20August%2010,%202010%20NYC%20Poll%20Release%20and%20Tables.pdf|archivedate=August 16, 2010|df=}} {{cite news |title=More than half of New York voters oppose Ground Zero mosque plan: poll |author=Samuel Goldsmith |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/07/01/2010-07-01_more_than_half_of_new_york_voters_oppose_ground_zero_mosque_plan_poll.html |work=Daily News |location=New York |date=July 1, 2010 |accessdate=July 31, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704051056/http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/07/01/2010-07-01_more_than_half_of_new_york_voters_oppose_ground_zero_mosque_plan_poll.html |archivedate=July 4, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2010/08/03/bloomberg1376-L6KYQQ6VJ6RL01-0S5L40PLCGTPOD0RS64DV6DMFD.DTL |author1=Simone Baribeau |author2=David Levitt |author3=Nicholas Johnston |author4=Stacie Servetah |author5=Mark Schoifet |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Ground Zero Mosque Plans Move Forward After Key Vote |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=August 3, 2010 |accessdate=August 4, 2010}} oppose it.{{cite web|url=http://www.quinnipiac.edu/x1318.xml?ReleaseID=1493 |title=9/11 Family Concerns Outweigh Muslim Right To Mosque, New York State Voters Tell Quinnipiac University Poll|publisher=Quinnipiac University Polling Institute|date=August 31, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904000358/http://www.quinnipiac.edu/x1318.xml?ReleaseID=1493|archivedate=September 4, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/08/13/fox-news-poll-percent-think-wrong-build-mosque-near-ground-zero/|author=Dana Blanton|title=Fox News Poll: 64 Percent Think It's Wrong to Build Mosque Near Ground Zero|publisher=Fox News|date=August 13, 2010|accessdate=August 31, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100902223619/http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/08/13/fox-news-poll-percent-think-wrong-build-mosque-near-ground-zero/|archivedate=September 2, 2010|df=}} Most Americans do, however, believe the Park51 developers have a legal right to proceed with the project.{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2010/08/islamic_cultural_centre_sorta_near_ground_zero |title=Mosque-building and its discontents |work=[[The Economist]]/''[[YouGov]]'' |date=August 19, 2010 |accessdate=September 19, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100902145200/http://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2010/08/islamic_cultural_centre_sorta_near_ground_zero |archivedate=September 2, 2010 |df= }} The project's organizers state that it is intended to be "a platform for [[Interfaith|multi-faith dialogue]]. It will strive to promote inter-community peace, tolerance and understanding locally in New York City, nationally in America, and globally," and have stated that it is modeled on the noted Manhattan [[Jewish Community Center]], the [[92nd Street Y]].{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/talk/comment/2010/08/16/100816taco_talk_hertzberg|title=Zero Grounds|work=The New Yorker|author=Hendrik Hertzberg|date=August 16, 2010|accessdate=August 21, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822000656/http://www.newyorker.com/talk/comment/2010/08/16/100816taco_talk_hertzberg|archivedate=August 22, 2010|df=}}{{cite news|url=http://forward.com/articles/128347/mosque-s-plan-to-expand-near-ground-zero-sparks//|title=Mosque's Plan To Expand Near Ground Zero Sparks Debate|author=Josh Nathan-Kazis|date=May 26, 2010|accessdate=September 19, 2012|work=The Jewish Daily Forward|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904053228/http://forward.com/articles/128347/mosque-s-plan-to-expand-near-ground-zero-sparks/|archivedate=September 4, 2012|df=}} The project's sponsors explained that the original name of the center was meant to invoke 8th–11th century [[Córdoba, Spain|Córdoba]], in Spain, which they call a model of [[La Convivencia|peaceful coexistence]] between [[Al-Andalus|Muslims]], [[Mozarab|Christians]], and [[Golden age of Jewish culture in Spain|Jews]]. The proposal triggered an intense nationwide controversy,{{cite news|author=Justin Elliott |title=How the "ground zero mosque" fear mongering began |url=http://www.salon.com/news/ground_zero_mosque/index.html?story=/politics/war_room/2010/08/16/ground_zero_mosque_origins |work=Salon |date=August 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100912103421/http://www.salon.com/news/ground_zero_mosque/index.html?story=%2Fpolitics%2Fwar_room%2F2010%2F08%2F16%2Fground_zero_mosque_origins |archivedate=September 12, 2010 }}{{cite news |title=Despite Protests, Mosque Plan Near 9/11 Site Wins Key Vote |author=Ray Sanchez |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/mosque-plan-clears-hurdle-protests/story?id=10747570 |publisher=ABC News |date=May 26, 2010 |accessdate=July 31, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529173246/http://abcnews.go.com/US/mosque-plan-clears-hurdle-protests/story?id=10747570 |archivedate=May 29, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/06/07/2010-06-07_1000_protest_islamic_center_plan.html |title=1,000 protest planned Islamic center, mosque near Ground Zero |work=Daily News |location=New York |date=June 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611011615/http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/06/07/2010-06-07_1000_protest_islamic_center_plan.html |archivedate=June 11, 2010 |df= }} with opponents of the project objecting to its proximity to the site of the September 11 attacks,{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/08/02/new-york-mosque-controversy-fires-national-campaign/ |author=James Rosen |title=New York Mosque Controversy Fires Up National Campaign |publisher=Fox News |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805105150/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/08/02/new-york-mosque-controversy-fires-national-campaign/ |archivedate=August 5, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news |author=Nicole Neroulias |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/life/religion/7131001.html |title=Quietly, another mosque operates in the shadow of Ground Zero |work=Houston Chronicle |date=July 29, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100801234944/http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/life/religion/7131001.html |archivedate=August 1, 2010 |df= }} its scale, sources of funding, or expressing concern that the project's name was intended as a reference to the Islamic conquest of the Christian city of Córdoba.{{cite news|url=http://www.aim.org/guest-column/the-consequences-of-park-51-the-cordoba-house/|title=The Consequences of Park51: The Cordoba House|publisher=Accuracy in Media|author=Frank Salvato|date=August 6, 2010|accessdate=August 6, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100817030011/http://www.aim.org/guest-column/the-consequences-of-park-51-the-cordoba-house/|archivedate=August 17, 2010|df=}} Supporters have appealed to the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] as well as the opportunity for Muslims to demonstrate peaceful Islamic values and for Americans to reassert their commitment to tolerance and diversity. ==Naming of the project== [[File:Park51 location map.png|thumb|The proposed location of Park51 is indicated by a red dot.]] The project was originally called Cordoba House, then renamed Park51, in reference to the street address on Park Place. Later, the Imam leading the project introduced some ambiguity by again referring to the project as "Cordoba House".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/08/opinion/08mosque.html|title=Building on Faith|author=Feisal Abdul Rauf|work=The New York Times|date=September 7, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170506002307/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/08/opinion/08mosque.html|archivedate=May 6, 2017|df=}} The Park51 website then clarified that Park51 is the community center, while Cordoba House is the "interfaith and religious component of the center".{{cite news |author=Dan Amira |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2010/07/ground_zero_mosque_gets_lets_m.html |title=Ground Zero Mosque Gets Less Muslim-Invasion-Sounding Name |work=New York |date=July 14, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719020940/http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2010/07/ground_zero_mosque_gets_lets_m.html |archivedate=July 19, 2010 |df= }} Cordoba Initiative said the name "Cordoba House" was meant to invoke [[Caliphate of Córdoba|8th–11th century]] [[Córdoba, Spain|Córdoba]], Spain, which they called a model of [[La Convivencia|peaceful coexistence]] among [[Al-Andalus|Muslims]], [[Mozarab|Christians]], and [[Golden age of Jewish culture in Spain|Jews]].{{cite news|author=Editorial|url=http://www.economist.com/node/16743239|title=Build that mosque: The campaign against the proposed Cordoba centre in New York is unjust and dangerous|date=August 5, 2010|accessdate=August 21, 2010|work=The Economist|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819033331/http://economist.com/node/16743239|archivedate=August 19, 2010|df=}} According to ''[[The Economist]]'', the name was chosen because Muslims, Jews, and Christians created a center of learning in Córdoba together. The name was criticized; for example, [[Newt Gingrich]] said that it was "a deliberately insulting term" that symbolizes the Muslim conquerors' victory over Christian Spaniards, and noted that the Muslims had converted a Cordoba church into the third largest [[mosque]] in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.newt.org/newt-direct/newt-gingrich-statement-proposed-mosqueislamic-community-center-near-ground-zero |title=Newt Gingrich Statement on Proposed Mosque/Islamic Community Center near Ground Zero |work=Newt Direct|date=July 21, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820114339/http://www.newt.org/newt-direct/newt-gingrich-statement-proposed-mosqueislamic-community-center-near-ground-zero|archivedate=August 20, 2010}} Similarly, [[Raymond Ibrahim]], a former associate director of the [[Middle East Forum]], said the project and name were not "a gesture of peace and interfaith dialogue" but were "allusive of Islamic conquest and consolidation" and that Americans should realize that mosques are not "Muslim counterparts to Christian churches" but rather, "are symbols of domination and centers of radicalization". The opposition to Park51 believes that Islam builds mosques on "conquered territory" as symbols of "territory" and "conquest".{{cite web|author=Raymond Ibrahim|url=http://www.meforum.org/2678/ground-zero-mosque|title=The Two Faces of the Ground Zero Mosque|publisher=Middle East Forum|date=June 22, 2010|accessdate=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628024326/http://www.meforum.org/2678/ground-zero-mosque|archivedate=June 28, 2010|df=}} Park51 is often referred to as the "Ground Zero mosque".{{cite news |author1=Kenneth Lovett |author2=Erik Badia |author3=Corky Siemaszko |lastauthoramp=yes |date=August 23, 2010 |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/08/23/2010-08-23_ground_zero_mosque_lone_man_stands_in_middle_of_park51_debate__literally.html |title=Archbishop Timothy Dolan, Gov. Paterson to huddle about mosque controversy |work=Daily News |location=New York |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100825163749/http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/08/23/2010-08-23_ground_zero_mosque_lone_man_stands_in_middle_of_park51_debate__literally.html |archivedate=August 25, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|title=When a 'Ground Zero mosque' really is neither|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2010-08-14/news/bs-md-marbella-ground-zero-mosque-20100814_1_ground-zero-mosque-vesey-street-hallowed-ground|date=August 14, 2010|author=Jean Marbella|work=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=August 19, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821095349/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2010-08-14/news/bs-md-marbella-ground-zero-mosque-20100814_1_ground-zero-mosque-vesey-street-hallowed-ground|archivedate=August 21, 2010|df=}} Since it is neither located directly on the former World Trade Center site, Ground Zero, nor primarily a mosque, some news media have advised against the use of this term. The Associated Press suggested several alternate terms including "mosque 2 blocks from WTC site", "Muslim (or Islamic) center near WTC site", "mosque near ground zero", and "mosque near WTC site".{{cite press release|url=http://www.ap.org/pages/about/pressreleases/pr_081910b.html|title=AP Standards Center issues staff advisory on covering New York City mosque|publisher=Associated Press|date=August 19, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100825013241/http://ap.org/pages/about/pressreleases/pr_081910b.html|archivedate=August 25, 2010|df=}} Cordoba Initiative says the building is not strictly a mosque.{{cite web | url=http://www.cordobainitiative.org/?q=content/frequently-asked-questions | title=Frequently Asked Questions | publisher=Cordoba Initiative | accessdate=October 6, 2010}} Anushay Hossain in ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' criticises the use of the name Ground Zero mosque, and says it is "Not a mosque but an Islamic Community Center".{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/anushay-hossain/park-51-the-ground-zero-m_b_686950.html | title=The Ground Zero "mosque" is not a mosque | work=The Huffington Post | accessdate=October 6, 2010 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160830203741/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/anushay-hossain/park-51-the-ground-zero-m_b_686950.html | archivedate=August 30, 2016 | df= }} Jean Marbella in ''The Baltimore Sun'' says the building is closer to a YMCA center than a house of worship. ==History== ===Site use=== ====Before 2001==== [[File:45 Park Place Manhattan 3.JPG|thumb|Slogans drawn by supporters on the pavement in front of the former Burlington Coat Factory, in 2010]] 45–47 Park Place was constructed between 1857 and 1858, in the [[Palazzo style architecture]]. The stone-faced building, designed by [[Daniel D. Badger]], was originally constructed for a shipping firm of a prominent New York shipping magnate.{{cite news|title=45 Park's Place |author=Emily Geminder |url=http://www.observer.com/2010/real-estate/45-park-place's-place |work=The New York Observer |date=July 20, 2010 |accessdate=August 4, 2010}}{{cite news |url=http://www.tribecatrib.com/news/2010/july/670_community-board-1-committee-supports-islamic-group-in-landmarks-case.html |title=CB1 Committee Rejects Islamic Group's Building as a Landmark |author=Matt Dunning |work=The Tribeca Trib |date=July 8, 2010 |accessdate=August 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717101941/http://www.tribecatrib.com/news/2010/july/670_community-board-1-committee-supports-islamic-group-in-landmarks-case.html |archivedate=July 17, 2011 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bbd29578-9f24-11df-8732-00144feabdc0.html |title='Ground Zero' mosque moves forward |work=[[Financial Times]] |date=August 3, 2010 |accessdate=August 4, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815051655/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bbd29578-9f24-11df-8732-00144feabdc0.html |archivedate=August 15, 2010 |df= }} Its Italian palazzo style was a throwback to a prior time of European grandeur, and was intended to evoke images of economic might. The building is an example of the "store and loft" structures that were prevalent in the [[dry goods]] warehouse districts of Lower Manhattan. The building was one of only a few stand-alone structures in southern [[Tribeca]] that were nominated – but never designated – as individual landmarks, during an effort in the 1980s to create a Tribeca historic district. In September 1989, the Commission had held public hearings and considered the building for landmark status, but it never acted on the matter, and the building was "calendared" ever since. By August 2010, city building records reflected that out of a group of 29 buildings that had been proposed for historic landmark designation in 1989, including 45–47 Park Place, twenty-three had been deemed landmarks and six were pending. The pending applications included 45–47 Park Place.{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/manhattan/landmark_vote_on_ground_zero_mosque_7iWKADGQO0hZKHkpSdxYWN|title=Landmark vote on Ground Zero mosque|author=Tom Topousis|date=August 3, 2010|work=New York Post|accessdate=August 3, 2010}} At that point, New York City had more than 11,000 landmarked buildings.{{cite news |author=Michael Howard Saul |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703545604575407131182033768?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Ground Zero Mosque-NYC Landmarks Commission Clears Way for Islamic Center |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=August 4, 2010 |accessdate=August 3, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222104910/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703545604575407131182033768?mod=googlenews_wsj |archivedate=February 22, 2018 |df= }} Muslims had a presence in Lower Manhattan for many years prior to the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001, attacks]]. At least two mosques existed near the World Trade Center,{{cite news |url=http://www.tribecatrib.com/newsfeb06/liquorstore.htm |author=Carl Glassman |title=West Broadway Bars Facing License Ban |work=[[The Tribeca Trib]] |date=April 5, 2007 |accessdate=August 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822124101/http://www.tribecatrib.com/newsfeb06/liquorstore.htm |archivedate=August 22, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/14/nyregion/14mosque.html | work=The New York Times | title=In Lower Manhattan, 2 Mosques Have Firm Roots | author=Anne Barnard | date=August 13, 2010 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219044009/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/14/nyregion/14mosque.html | archivedate=December 19, 2016 | df= }} and several designated Muslim prayer rooms existed within the World Trade Center buildings.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/11/nyregion/11religion.html?src=tp | work=The New York Times | title=Muslims and Islam Were Part of Twin Towers' Life | author=Samuel Freedman | date=September 10, 2010 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827132630/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/11/nyregion/11religion.html?src=tp | archivedate=August 27, 2017 | df= }} ====September 11, 2001, attacks==== [[File:World Trade Center, NY - 2001-09-11 - Debris Impact Areas.svg|thumb|A diagram showing the areas where debris from [[American Airlines Flight 11]] and [[United Airlines Flight 175]] fell upon Lower Manhattan during the course of the September 11 terror attacks.]] During the September 11 attacks, the then-five-story building at 45–47 Park Place, between [[West Broadway (Manhattan)|West Broadway]] and [[Church Street (Manhattan)|Church Street]], was severely damaged.{{cite news |title=Vote Endorses Muslim Center Near Ground Zero |author=Javier C. Hernandez |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/26/nyregion/26muslim.html |work=The New York Times |date=May 25, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605134214/http://www.nytimes.com//2010//05//26//nyregion//26muslim.html |archivedate=June 5, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://www.tribecatrib.com/news/2010/may/603_cb1-committee-hails-plans-for-a-mosque-two-blocks-from-world-trade-center-site.html |author=Matt Dunning |title=CB1 Committee Hails Plans for a Mosque Two Blocks from WTC Site |work=[[The Tribeca Trib]] |date=May 6, 2010 |accessdate=August 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528024505/http://www.tribecatrib.com/news/2010/may/603_cb1-committee-hails-plans-for-a-mosque-two-blocks-from-world-trade-center-site.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010 }} When [[United Airlines Flight 175]] struck the South Tower of the World Trade Center, part of the plane's [[landing gear]], [[engine]] and [[fuselage]] came out the north side of the tower and crashed through the roof of 45–47 Park Place, and through two of its floors. The plane parts destroyed three floor beams, and severely compromised the building's internal structure.{{cite news |title=Planned Sign of Tolerance Bringing Division Instead |author=Javier C. Hernandez |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/14/nyregion/14center.html |work=The New York Times |date=July 13, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103054445/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/14/nyregion/14center.html |archivedate=November 3, 2012 |df= }}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7fBUAAAAMAAJ&q=%22park+place%22+%22landing+gear%22&dq=%22park+place%22+%22landing+gear%22&hl=en&ei=TthXTPKKPIL78AaK-rSrCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBQ|author=Structural Engineers Association of New York, Noah Klersfeld, Guy Nordenson and Associates, LZA Technology|title=World Trade Center emergency damage assessment of buildings: Structural Engineers Association of New York inspections of September and October 2001|volume=1|publisher=Structural Engineers Association of New York|year=2003|accessdate=August 3, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921063933/http://books.google.com/books?id=7fBUAAAAMAAJ&q=%22park+place%22+%22landing+gear%22&dq=%22park+place%22+%22landing+gear%22&hl=en&ei=TthXTPKKPIL78AaK-rSrCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBQ|archivedate=September 21, 2013|df=}} The damage was not immediately noticed during an exterior assessment. It was later discovered during an interior assessment.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PJ3bfaDVcvMC&pg=SA7-PA17&dq=%2245+Park+Place%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-zp8Ue_FArS30QG5tYGoBg&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=%2245%20Park%20Place%22&f=false|title=World Trade Center Building Performance Study: Data Collection, Preliminary Observations, and Recommendations|author1=Federal Emergency Management Agency|author2=Federal Insurance and Mitigation Administration|year=2002|publisher=Government Printing Office|accessdate=April 27, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921064403/http://books.google.com/books?id=PJ3bfaDVcvMC&pg=SA7-PA17&dq=%2245+Park+Place%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-zp8Ue_FArS30QG5tYGoBg&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=%2245%20Park%20Place%22&f=false|archivedate=September 21, 2013|df=}} In April 2013, the New York Police Department announced that surveyors inspecting the building had discovered a {{convert|17|in|cm|adj=on}} wide piece, {{convert|5|ft|m|spell=in}} long airplane part complete with Boeing identification number wedged in an {{convert|18|in|cm|adj=on}} wide alley between 51 Park and 50 Murray Street. Initially officials thought it was part of the landing gear but Boeing confirmed it was the trailing edge flap actuation support structure of an airplane [[Flap (aircraft)|flap]] from a Boeing 767, the type of jet which hit both towers. A photograph of the piece initially showed a rope around it. Police said the rope was used by an officer who lassoed it to see the identification number. Boeing could not say which specific plane it was from.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/landing-gear-mosque-9-11-plane-boeing-article-1.1330196|title=9/11 mom angry at city after plane part discovery|publisher=|accessdate=8 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822101920/http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/landing-gear-mosque-9-11-plane-boeing-article-1.1330196|archivedate=22 August 2016|df=}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/26/911-plane-landing-gear-lower-manhattan-nypd-51-park-place_n_3165651.html|title=9/11 Plane's Landing Gear Found In Lower Manhattan, Says NYPD (PHOTOS)|work=The Huffington Post|date=April 26, 2013|accessdate=April 26, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130427103612/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/26/911-plane-landing-gear-lower-manhattan-nypd-51-park-place_n_3165651.html|archivedate=April 27, 2013|df=}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/181146/officials-to-search-for-human-remains-in-alley-with-9-11-hijacked-plane-remnant |title=Officials To Search For Human Remains In Alley With 9/11 Hijacked Plane Remnant |publisher=NY1 |date=March 30, 2010 |accessdate=April 27, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502014922/http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/181146/officials-to-search-for-human-remains-in-alley-with-9-11-hijacked-plane-remnant |archivedate=May 2, 2013 |df= }} ====2001–2009==== The 45–47 Park Place building, located about two blocks ({{convert|600|ft|m|sp=us|disp=or|abbr=off}}) north of the [[World Trade Center site]], was owned by Stephen Pomerantz and his wife Kukiko Mitani and leased to the [[Burlington Coat Factory]]. For years, Mitani attempted to sell the building, at one point asking for $18 million. It lay abandoned until its purchase in July 2009. For several months thereafter, the building was used as an overflow prayer space for up to 450 Muslims, with services led by [[Feisal Abdul Rauf]], an [[Imam]] based at the al-Farah mosque in nearby [[TriBeCa]].{{cite news|url=http://www.observer.com/2010/real-estate/landmarks-vote-potential-mosque-site-tuesday|title=Landmarks to Vote Tuesday on Potential Mosque Site|author=Sam Levin|work=The New York Observer|date=July 30, 2010|accessdate=August 2, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100801053605/http://www.observer.com/2010/real-estate/landmarks-vote-potential-mosque-site-tuesday|archivedate=August 1, 2010|df=}}{{cite news |title=Muslim Prayers and Renewal Near Ground Zero |author1=Ralph Blumenthal |author2=Sharaf Mowjood |lastauthoramp=yes |work=The New York Times |date=December 9, 2009 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/09/nyregion/09mosque.html |accessdate=July 31, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100826202236/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/09/nyregion/09mosque.html |archivedate=August 26, 2010 |df= }} ===Purchase and investors=== In July 2009, the real estate company and developer [[Soho Properties]] purchased the building and property at 45–47 Park Place for $4.85 million in cash.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/05/14/plan-build-mosque-near-ground-zero-riles-families-victims/|title=Plan to Build Mosque Near Ground Zero Riles Families of 9/11 Victims|author=Lauren Green|date=April 7, 2010|accessdate=August 3, 2010|publisher=Fox News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805055517/http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/05/14/plan-build-mosque-near-ground-zero-riles-families-victims/|archivedate=August 5, 2010|df=}}{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/anger-over-mosque-plan-for-ground-zero/story-e6frf7jx-1225866534163 |title=Anger over mosque plan for Ground Zero |work=Herald Sun |location=Melbourne |date=May 14, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }} Soho Properties' Chairman and CEO, [[Sharif El-Gamal]], initially planned to build a condominium complex at the site, but was convinced by [[Imam]] [[Feisal Abdul Rauf]]'s idea for a community center with a prayer space.{{cite news |title=Zero tolerance and Cordoba House |author=Peer Basharat |work=Financial Times |date=August 13, 2010 |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/bf1110d8-a5b0-11df-a5b7-00144feabdc0.html |accessdate=August 20, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819041647/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/bf1110d8-a5b0-11df-a5b7-00144feabdc0.html |archivedate=August 19, 2010 |df= }} El-Gamal's partner is Nour Mousa, the nephew of [[Amr Moussa]], the Secretary General of the [[Arab League]].{{cite news|title=A Mosque Grows Near Brooklyn; The dubious financing of 'Cordoba House' deserves scrutiny |author=Stephen Schwartz |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/articles/mosque-grows-near-brooklyn?page=2 |work=The Weekly Standard|date=July 26, 2010 |accessdate=August 9, 2010}}{{cite press release|title=Muslim 6, 2010|df=}}[[File:Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf (1).jpg|thumb|Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf]] The investors in the transaction were the Cordoba Initiative, a tax-exempt foundation with assets of $20,000, and the American Society for Muslim Advancement (ASMA),{{cite web|url=http://www.asmasociety.org/about/b_dkhan.html|title=Daisy Khan|publisher=American Society for Muslim Advancement|accessdate=August 3, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727181140/http://www.asmasociety.org/about/b_dkhan.html|archivedate=July 27, 2010|df=}} also a non-profit organization. At the time, Rauf was founder, CEO, and Executive Director of Cordoba Initiative, and founder and CEO of ASMA, and his wife, Daisy Khan, was the ASMA Executive Director.{{cite news|url=http://www.9wsyr.com/news/local/story/NYC-community-board-OKs-ground-zero-mosque-plans/z5sEUmYDVUGS013D6xretw.cspx|title=NYC community board OKs ground zero mosque plans|publisher=[[WSYR-TV|WSYR]]|date=May 26, 2010|accessdate=August 2, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100530081404/http://www.9wsyr.com/news/local/story/NYC-community-board-OKs-ground-zero-mosque-plans/z5sEUmYDVUGS013D6xretw.cspx|archivedate=May 30, 2010|df=}} In the Cordoba Initiative's first five years, from 2004–08, it raised less than $100,000.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/9065537 |title=Mosque going up in NYC building damaged on 9/11 |author=Cristian Salazar |work=The Guardian |date=May 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921163910/http://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/9065537 |archivedate=September 21, 2013 |df= }} Both organizations were run out of the same New York office.{{cite web|url=http://www.asmasociety.org/about/b_rauf.html|title=Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf|publisher=American Society for Muslim Advancement|accessdate=August 3, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150809135542/http://www.asmasociety.org/about/b_rauf.html|archivedate=August 9, 2015|df=}} The two foundations proposed to use the property as the site for a $100 million community center modeled after NYC's Jewish Community Centers and YMCAs.{{cite news |url=http://www.torontosun.com/comment/2010/07/26/14835681.html |title=Monument to Jihad; Ground Zero Mosque No Joke |work=Toronto Sun |date=July 27, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727160129/http://www.torontosun.com/comment/2010/07/26/14835681.html |archivedate=July 27, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/07/30/imam-faisal-ground-zero-mosque-money-opinions-columnists-claudia-rosett.html?boxes=financechannelforbes |title=Where In The World Is Imam Feisal? |author=Claudia Rosett |work=Forbes |date=July 30, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802032658/http://www.forbes.com/2010/07/30/imam-faisal-ground-zero-mosque-money-opinions-columnists-claudia-rosett.html?boxes=financechannelforbes |archivedate=August 2, 2010 |df= }} They were working on the project with El-Gamal, their co-developer.{{cite news |url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20100725/REAL_ESTATE/100729901 |title=Mosque madness a matter of perspective; Locals welcome $100M project, but others side with Palin to say no way |author=Amanda Fung |work=Crain's New York Business |date=July 25, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727212453/http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20100725/REAL_ESTATE/100729901 |archivedate=July 27, 2010 |df= }} The 49–51 Park Place half of the "45–51" parcel was still owned by the utility [[Con Edison]] (Con Ed).{{cite news|author=Mike Vilensky|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2010/08/mosque.html|title='Ground Zero Mosque' Developers Still Need to Snag Half the Property From Con Ed|work=New York|date=August 6, 2010|accessdate=August 8, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819200032/http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2010/08/mosque.html|archivedate=August 19, 2010|df=}} Soho Properties paid an additional $700,000 to assume a $33,000-a-year lease with Con Ed, for its adjacent attached former sub-station. The plan was to build the facility on the site of the two buildings, as the lease for 49–51 Park Place was expire in 2071. The two buildings were connected internally, with common walls having been taken down. El-Gamal informed Con Ed in February 2010 that he wanted to exercise his purchase option on the lease. Although the price was reportedly estimated at $10–$20 million, El-Gamal said the cost "is not an issue".{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/manhattan/half_baked_mosque_8ItuaW0WIByZa5xZ0rCmpJ#ixzz0w1QbwRx5|title=Half-baked mosque|author1=Isabel Vincent|date=August 8, 2010|work=New York Post|accessdate=August 8, 2010|author2=Melissa Klein|lastauthoramp=yes}} The sale was to be reviewed by the [[New York Public Service Commission]], where it might face a vote by a five-member board controlled by the New York governor's office. The specific location of the planned facility, "where a piece of the wreckage fell", so close to the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]], was a primary selling point for the Muslims who bought the building. Rauf said it "sends the opposite statement to what happened on 9/11" and "We want to push back against the extremists." [[File:12.19.10Park51byLuigiNovi3.jpg|thumb|right|The former Burlington Coat Factory buildings at 45–51 Park Place, in 2010]] ===Planned facilities=== While the media widely described the center as a mosque, and the protests were against the mosque, the Initiative's official blog portrayed it as a community center with prayer space, making comparisons to the [[YMCA]] or [[Jewish Community Center]].{{cite web|title=What is a Community Center?|url=http://cordobainitiative.wordpress.com/2010/07/01/what-is-a-community-center/|date=July 1, 2010|publisher=The Cordoba Initiative|accessdate=July 29, 2010}} The Initiative said that some services planned for Park51 such as the restaurant and performance center, disqualify it from being a mosque.{{cite web|title=What is Prayer Space?|url=http://cordobainitiative.wordpress.com/2010/07/06/what-is-prayer-space/|publisher=The Cordoba Initiative|accessdate=August 11, 2010}} Daisy Khan, Imam Rauf's wife and partner, in August 2010 also said: {{quote|We insist on calling it a prayer space and not a mosque, because you can use a prayer space for activities apart from prayer. You can't stop anyone who is a Muslim despite his religious ideology from entering the mosque and staying there. With a prayer space, we can control who gets to use it.}} The official website for the facility had said it would include "a mosque, intended to be run separately from Park51 but open to and accessible to all members, visitors and our New York community".{{cite web|title=Facilities|url=http://www.park51.org/facilities.htm|publisher=Park51|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719005731/http://www.park51.org/facilities.htm|archivedate=July 19, 2010}} By September 2010, the word mosque had been replaced with "prayer space".{{cite web|url=http://blog.park51.org/?page_id=23|title=Facilities|publisher=Park51|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100911074717/http://blog.park51.org/?page_id=23|archivedate=September 11, 2010}} In an interview in July 2010, lead developer of the project Sharif el-Gamal had supported the inclusion of a mosque as needed by the New York Muslim community.{{cite web|url=http://blog.beliefnet.com/cityofbrass/2010/07/qa-with-sharif-el-gamal-about.html|title=Q&A with Sharif el-Gamal about Park51, NYC|publisher=[[Beliefnet]]|date=July 25, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830221027/http://blog.beliefnet.com/cityofbrass/2010/07/qa-with-sharif-el-gamal-about.html|archivedate=August 30, 2010|df=}} The Muslim prayer space is planned to occupy two floors of the 13 story building.{{cite news |title=Better mosque compromise: Chair of community board wants interfaith center inside Park51 project |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/opinions/2010/08/30/2010-08-30_better_mosque_compromise_chair_of_community_board_wants_interfaith_center_inside.html |author=Julie Menin |work=Daily News |location=New York |date=August 30, 2010 |accessdate=September 21, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100903160436/http://www.nydailynews.com/opinions/2010/08/30/2010-08-30_better_mosque_compromise_chair_of_community_board_wants_interfaith_center_inside.html |archivedate=September 3, 2010 |df= }} Besides the prayer space, the Initiative's plan includes a 500-seat auditorium, theater, performing arts center, [[fitness center]], swimming pool, basketball court, childcare services, art exhibitions, bookstore, culinary school, and a food court serving [[halal]] dishes.{{cite news |title=Debate Heats Up About Mosque Near Ground Zero |author=Michael Barbaro |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/31/nyregion/31mosque.html |work=The New York Times |date=July 30, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111115182106/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/31/nyregion/31mosque.html |archivedate=November 15, 2011 |df= }} El-Gamal said he wanted the building to be energy-efficient and transparent, most likely with a glass façade.{{cite news |author=Anton Troianovski |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704196404575375260371805650 |title=Developer Envisions Landmark Mosque |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=July 19, 2010 |accessdate=August 3, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160131044615/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704196404575375260371805650 |archivedate=January 31, 2016 |df= }} The project envisions the demolition of two buildings at 45–47 Park Place and Broadway which were damaged on 9/11. They would be replaced by a glass and steel {{convert|100000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} structure with a new address, 45–51 Park Place. A number of commentators stated that the builders planned either the groundbreaking or opening date to coincide with anniversaries of the September 11 attacks.{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/comment/columnists/peter_worthington/2010/08/04/14926731.html|title=Zero thinking at Ground Zero|author=Peter Worthington|work=Toronto Sun|date=August 4, 2010|accessdate=August 5, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805092035/http://www.torontosun.com/comment/columnists/peter_worthington/2010/08/04/14926731.html|archivedate=August 5, 2010|df=}}{{cite news|author=Judy McLeod|url=http://canadafreepress.com/index.php/article/26172|title=No words can ease the heartache of Ground Zero "mega mosque"|work=Canada Free Press|date=August 4, 2010|accessdate=August 4, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029034720/http://canadafreepress.com/index.php/article/26172|archivedate=October 29, 2010|df=}}{{cite news |title=September 11, 2010. Protest the 911 Mega Mosque at Ground Zero |author=Pamela Geller |work=Atlas Shrugged |date=August 6, 2010 |url=http://atlasshrugs2000.typepad.com/atlas_shrugs/2010/08/september-11-2010-protest-the-911-mega-mosque-at-ground-zero.html |accessdate=August 31, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815043611/http://atlasshrugs2000.typepad.com/atlas_shrugs/2010/08/september-11-2010-protest-the-911-mega-mosque-at-ground-zero.html |archivedate=August 15, 2010 |df=}} Khan said in a July 2010 conversation with [[Media Matters for America]] that such assertions were "absolutely false" and that the construction timeline had not been determined; furthermore, those making such assertions have no proof of their claims.{{cite news |url=http://mediamatters.org/research/201007200004 |title=Why is Fox pushing a falsehood to fuel outrage over NYC Muslim community center? |publisher=Media Matters for America |date=July 20, 2010 |accessdate=August 4, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100803033453/http://mediamatters.org/research/201007200004 |archivedate=August 3, 2010 |df= }} However, in a May 2010 Associated Press interview Khan said that the Initiative may plan for groundbreaking to coincide with the 10th anniversary of the attacks.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2010-05-07-mosque-ground-zero_N.htm |title=Building damaged in 9/11 to be mosque for NYC Muslims |work=USA Today |date=May 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 26, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100902235859/http://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2010-05-07-mosque-ground-zero_N.htm |archivedate=September 2, 2010 |df= }} Khan also said that it was anticipated that 1,000 to 2,000 Muslims would pray at the prayer center every Friday, once it was completed.{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/05/06/2010-05-06_plan_for_mosque_near_world_trade_center_site_moves_ahead.html |title=Plan for mosque near World Trade Center site moves ahead |author1=Joe Jackson |author2=Bill Hutchinson |lastauthoramp=yes |work=Daily News |location=New York |date=May 6, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100510081825/http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/05/06/2010-05-06_plan_for_mosque_near_world_trade_center_site_moves_ahead.html |archivedate=May 10, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2010/06/06/a_mosque_at_ground_zero/ |title=A mosque at ground zero? |author=Jeff Jacoby |work=The Boston Globe |date=June 6, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724144806/http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2010/06/06/a_mosque_at_ground_zero/ |archivedate=July 24, 2010 |df= }} Khan said the project is intended to foster better relations between Islam and Americans.{{cite news |title=Mosque to go up near New York's ground zero |author=Nicole Bliman |publisher=CNN |date=May 7, 2010 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/US/05/07/new.york.ground.zero.mosque/index.html?hpt=Mid |accessdate=July 31, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722044452/http://www.cnn.com/2010/US/05/07/new.york.ground.zero.mosque/index.html?hpt=Mid |archivedate=July 22, 2010 |df= }} Explaining the choice of location, she said, "We decided we wanted to look at the legacy of 9/11 and do something positive." She added that her group represents moderate Muslims who want "to reverse the trend of extremism and the kind of ideology that the extremists are spreading".{{cite news |title=Near Ground Zero, a Mosque Moves In and Meets the Neighbors |author=Aaron Rutkoff |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=May 5, 2010 |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2010/05/05/near-ground-zero-a-mosque-moves-in-and-meets-the-neighbors/ |accessdate=July 31, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100803151843/http://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2010/05/05/near-ground-zero-a-mosque-moves-in-and-meets-the-neighbors/ |archivedate=August 3, 2010 |df= }} Pointing to the fact that ordinary Muslims have been killed by Muslim extremists all over the world, Khan also said about the center, "For us it is a symbol... that will give voice to the silent majority of Muslims who suffer at the hands of extremists. |author=Nancy Fuchs Kreimer |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/nancy-fuchs-kreimer/proposed-muslim-community_b_583437.html |work=The Huffington Post |date=May 21, 2010 |accessdate=July 31, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100530112517/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/nancy-fuchs-kreimer/proposed-muslim-community_b_583437.html |archivedate=May 30, 2010 |df= }} ===Community board advisory vote=== On May 25, 2010, the local [[Community Boards in New York City|community board]] backed part of the plans for Cordoba House to be built on the site in a non-binding advisory vote of 29-to-1, with 10 abstentions.{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2010/05/25/nyc_community_board_oks_ground_zero_mosque_plans/ |title=NYC community board OKs ground zero mosque plans |work=The Boston Globe |date=May 25, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830223801/http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2010/05/25/nyc_community_board_oks_ground_zero_mosque_plans/ |archivedate=August 30, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://www.tribecatrib.com/news/2010/may/617_cb1-backs-imams-community-center-but-stays-silent-on-mosque-near-wtc.html |title=CB1 Backs Imam's Community Center, Silent on Mosque Near WTC |author=Matt Dunning |work=The Tribeca Trib |date=May 26, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806113717/http://www.tribecatrib.com/news/2010/may/617_cb1-backs-imams-community-center-but-stays-silent-on-mosque-near-wtc.html |archivedate=August 6, 2010 }}{{cite news |title=Plan For Mosque Next to Ground Zero in NYC Moves Forward |author=Mark Memmott |publisher=NPR |date=May 6, 2010 |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2010/05/mosque_ground_zero_world_trade.html |accessdate=July 31, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100513072422/http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2010/05/mosque_ground_zero_world_trade.html |archivedate=May 13, 2010 |df= }} The endorsement related only to "the important community facilities [the project] will provide", and the resolution indicated that the board "takes no position regarding the religious aspects or any religious facilities associated with either the Cordoba Initiative or the Cordoba House Project". The board's chairwoman, [[Julie Menin]], supported deletion of references to the building as a mosque and interfaith center that were in an earlier draft of the resolution, saying: "I personally was uncomfortable with the language that talked about the religious institution. I believe it's not the purview of a city agency to be weighing in on the siting of any religious institution, be it a mosque, synagogue, or church." The meeting where the vote was held was contentious. Some of the speakers supporting the project were Muslims who lost family members in the attacks, and were booed by protesters. Some non-Muslim relatives of 9/11 victims also spoke in support, but other family members objected to the project, claiming the location is insensitive.{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/05/26/2010-05-26_clash_over_mosque_heated_debate_on_a_house_of_worship_near_ground_zero.html |title=Supporters, opponents debate merits of controversial plan to build mosque near Ground Zero |author1=Rob Sgobbo |author2=Samuel Goldsmith |lastauthoramp=yes |work=Daily News |location=New York |date=May 26, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529163645/http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/05/26/2010-05-26_clash_over_mosque_heated_debate_on_a_house_of_worship_near_ground_zero.html |archivedate=May 29, 2010 |df= }}{{cite web | author = Julie Shapiro | title = Community Board Approves Mosque Near World Trade Center Site After Emotional Meeting | publisher = DNAinfo New York | location = Manhattan | date = May 26, 2010 | url = http://dnainfo.com/20100525/manhattan/meeting-on-planned-mosque-near-world-trade-center-site-draws-hundreds-of-people | accessdate = August 26, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100821210740/http://dnainfo.com/20100525/manhattan/meeting-on-planned-mosque-near-world-trade-center-site-draws-hundreds-of-people | archivedate = August 21, 2010 | df = }} ===Landmark status declined and litigation=== As the controversy grew New York City's [[Landmarks Preservation Commission]] agreed to reconsider the 1980s landmark application which it had not acted on previously. On August 3, 2010, it voted 9–0 against granting landmark status and historic protection to the building. That cleared the way for it to be demolished, and the new Cordoba House to be built in its place. The following day, Timothy Brown, a firefighter who survived 9/11, filed a lawsuit in [[New York State Supreme Court]] in Manhattan asking the court to nullify the Commission's decision.{{cite news |author=Andy Newman |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/08/04/in-battle-over-mosque-a-defender-of-architecture/ |title=In Battle Over Mosque, a Defender of Architecture |work=The New York Times |date=August 4, 2010 |accessdate=August 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805115247/http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/08/04/in-battle-over-mosque-a-defender-of-architecture/ |archivedate=August 5, 2010 |df= }}{{cite press release|url=http://www.businesswire.com/portal/site/home/permalink/?ndmViewId=news_view&newsId=20100804006720&newsLang=en |title=ACLJ Files Lawsuit Urging NY Court to Nullify Landmarks Commission Vote Clearing Way for Ground Zero Mosque |publisher=Business Wire|date=August 5, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811083107/http://www.businesswire.com/portal/site/home/permalink/?ndmViewId=news_view&newsId=20100804006720&newsLang=en|archivedate=August 11, 2010}}[http://www.aclj.org/media/pdf/ACLJ_EXECUTED-PETITION_20100804.pdf "Notice of Petition"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203145916/http://www.aclj.org/media/pdf/ACLJ_EXECUTED-PETITION_20100804.pdf |date=2010-12-03 }}, ''Brown v. New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission'', [[Supreme Court of the State of New York]], August 4, 2010. Retrieved August 9, 2010. He praised 45–47 Park Place, quoting the Commission's own description of it as "a fine example of the Italian Renaissance-inspired palazzi" that flourished in the mid-19th century in the area. The suit was filed on his behalf by the [[American Center for Law and Justice]], a conservative public interest firm.{{cite news |title=My take: Christian group is latest ground zero hypocrite |author=Stephen Prothero |authorlink=Stephen Prothero |url=http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2010/08/06/my-take-christian-group-is-latest-ground-zero-hypocrite/ |publisher=CNN |date=August 6, 2010 |accessdate=August 9, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100902172058/http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2010/08/06/my-take-christian-group-is-latest-ground-zero-hypocrite/ |archivedate=September 2, 2010 |df= }} On July 10, 2011, Justice Paul G. Feinman of the [[New York State Supreme Court]] dismissed Brown's case, writing that the firefighter was "an individual with a strong interest in preservation of the building", but added that he lacked any special legal standing regarding its fate. [[Adam Leitman Bailey]], the lawyer who represented the Islamic center's developer [[pro bono]], called the decision "a victory for America" and said, "Despite the tempest of religious hatred, the judge flexed our Constitution's muscles enforcing the very bedrock of our democracy." Jack Lester, a lawyer for Brown, said, "We believe the brave men and women who risked their lives have standing to preserve the monuments and historic buildings at ground zero." {{cite news|last=Moynihan|first=Colin|title=Judge Rules Ex-Firefighter Can't Sue Over carpeted prayer room is located in the lower level. In August 2011, ''The New York Times'' reported that Sharif El-Gamal, the project's developer, was quietly proceeding with efforts to move Park51 forward, embracing a "slower, more deliberate and more realistic approach" than before.{{cite news|last=Barnard|first=Anne|title=Developers of Islamic Center Try a New Strategy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/02/nyregion/new-quiet-effort-for-big-islamic-center-near-ground-zero.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 2, 2011|accessdate=August 2, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131201071345/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/02/nyregion/new-quiet-effort-for-big-islamic-center-near-ground-zero.html|archivedate=December 1, 2013|df=}} However, in April 2014, Sharif El-Gamal announced his plans to demolish the current building and replace it with a three-story museum of Islamic culture. He hired French architect [[Jean Nouvel]].{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/religion/site-of-proposed-ground-zero-mosque-may-become-a-museum/2014/04/30/50c18e62-d0a6-11e3-a714-be7e7f142085_story.html|title=Site of proposed Ground Zero mosque may become a museum|author=Omar Sacirbey|date=April 30, 2014|newspaper=Washington Post|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140507012402/http://www.washingtonpost.com/national/religion/site-of-proposed-ground-zero-mosque-may-become-a-museum/2014/04/30/50c18e62-d0a6-11e3-a714-be7e7f142085_story.html|archivedate=May 7, 2014|df=}} In late August 2014, the ''Times'' announced that the original mosque plans would not proceed. Instead, a three-story Islamic museum with a prayer space and condos would be built at 49-51 Park Place, which at the time was the location of a [[Con Edison]] building. ===Funding=== Imam Abdul Rauf promised to identify all financial backers of Park51.Caruso, David.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iNLTahM5QJw8Ts0SpTgWLjXwN7gAD9I435J80 AP Exclusive: Backers of NYC mosque appear divided] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100912150228/http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iNLTahM5QJw8Ts0SpTgWLjXwN7gAD9I435J80 |date=2010-09-12 }}, ''[[Associated Press]]''. Sep 8, 2010. Developer Sharif El-Gamal had stated that they will refuse money from groups such as the government of Iran and Hamas as well as any other "organizations that have un-American values".{{cite news |author=Brian Montopoli |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20014959-503544.html |title="Ground Zero Mosque" Developer Sharif El-Gamal: No Money from Iran, Hamas |work=Political Hotsheet |publisher=CBS News |date=August 27, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100915121803/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20014959-503544.html |archivedate=September 15, 2010 |df= }} ''[[The New York Post]]'' stated that initially Imam Abdul Rauf said the project would be funded entirely by the Muslim American community,{{cite news |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/opinion/editorials/money_behind_the_mosque_SZDcDNLjX4SwxHmwtES5mK |title=Money Behind the Mosque – Opinion |author=Editorial |work=New York Post |date=August 4, 2010 |accessdate=August 17, 2010}} though later he told London-based Arabic-language newspaper ''[[Asharq Al-Awsat]]'' that he would seek funding from Muslim and Arab nations.{{cite web|url=http://www.asharq-e.com/news.asp?section=1&id=20990|title=Controversy Rages in NYC over Planned Mosque Near Ground Zero|author=Mohammed Al Shafey|date=May 18, 2010|work=[[Asharq Al-Awsat]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707174226/http://www.asharq-e.com/news.asp?section=1&id=20990|archivedate=July 7, 2011|deadurl=yes|accessdate=August 17, 2010|df=}} The latter story was also reported by [[NBC]].{{cite news |author=Gabe Pressman |url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local-beat/Should-the-Mosque-Be-Built-----Follow-the-Money--99967009.html |title=Should the Mosque Be Built? – Follow the Money |publisher=WNBC |date=August 5, 2010 |accessdate=August 5, 2010}}{{cite news |author=Jillian Scharr |url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local-beat/Jewish-Leaders-Gather-to-Support-Ground-Zero-Mosque-100049479.html |title=Jewish Leaders Gather to Support Ground Zero Mosque |publisher=WNBC |date=August 17, 2010 |accessdate=August 17, 2010}} [[Claudia Rosett]], a journalist with the [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] and a weekly columnist for ''[[Forbes]]'', questioned the source of the funding for the project.{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/08/06/imam-feisal-ground-zero-mosque-opinions-columnists-claudia-rosett.html |title=Further Travels Of Imam Feisal – Opinion |author=Claudia Rosett |work=Forbes |date=August 6, 2010 |accessdate=September 14, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815070924/http://www.forbes.com/2010/08/06/imam-feisal-ground-zero-mosque-opinions-columnists-claudia-rosett.html |archivedate=August 15, 2010 }} Some U.S. politicians such as Connecticut Senator [[Joe Lieberman]], an [[Independent Democrat]], and Republicans [[Peter T. King|Peter King]] and [[Rick Lazio]], asked for an investigation of the group's finances, especially its foreign funding, despite the fact that fundraising for the project had not yet begun.{{cite news |author=Devlin Barret |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2010/08/03/mosque-debate-isnt-going-away/ |title=Mosque Debate Isn't Going Away |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=August 3, 2010 |accessdate=August 4, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100804061831/http://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2010/08/03/mosque-debate-isnt-going-away/ |archivedate=August 4, 2010 |df= }} King said: "The people who are involved in the construction of the mosque are refusing to say where their [$100 million] funding is going to come from."{{cite news|url=http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/70234 |title=NY Congressman Calls for Probe of Funding for Mosque Near Ground Zero and Its Promoter |author=Nick Dean |publisher=CNS News |date=September 30, 2001 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100731185354/http://cnsnews.com/news/article/70234 |archivedate=July 31, 2010 }}{{cite news |url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/religion/Muslim-Group-Faces-Opposition-Near-New-Yorks-Ground-Zero-99049124.html |title=Muslim Group Faces Opposition Near New York's Ground Zero |author=Carolyn Weaver |publisher=[[Voice of America]] |date=July 22, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728223028/http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/religion/Muslim-Group-Faces-Opposition-Near-New-Yorks-Ground-Zero-99049124.html |archivedate=July 28, 2010 |df= }} Lazio said: "Let's have transparency. If they're foreign governments, we ought to know about it. If they're radical organizations, we ought to know about it." Dr. [[Zuhdi Jasser]], President of the [[American Islamic Forum for Democracy]], called for transparency in the funding of the project, suggesting foreign sources could imply an ulterior agenda. Reza Aslan responded to Dr. Jasser's demand by saying that it was "absurd" to assume that overseas funding must necessarily involve extremism. He also said that it would be acceptable to demand mosques to be transparent about funding if the same was also demanded of a [[Catholic]] church or a Jewish temple. Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] said: "Where does [the money] come from?' I don't know. Do you really want every time they pass the basket in your church, and you throw a buck in, they run over and say, '... where do you come from? ... Where did you get this money?' No."{{cite news |author=Michael Howard |title=Mayor Sparks Mosque Fray |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=August 7, 2010 }} The TV news anchor [[Rick Sanchez]] said: "...if you start going into who is giving money to whom ... you have to go to my church. You have got to go to [[Rome]] and start asking where the money is going into Rome. And you have to go to the [[Mormon]]s and ask them, well, what are they doing with their money?"{{cite news |author=Rick Sanchez |publisher=CNN |date=August 11, 2010 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 |url=http://ricksanchez.blogs.cnn.com/2010/08/11/fmr-new-york-governor-pataki-thoughts-on-the-ground-zero-muslim-cultural-center/ |title=Fmr. N.Y. Gov. Pataki's thoughts on Ground Zero Islamic Cultural Center/Mosque |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805031445/http://www.mpac.org/article.php?id=1176 |archivedate=August 5, 2010 |df= }} Vogel and Russonello cite claims that donations "totaling $900,000, that the government of Qatar and a foundation run by Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal have made to nonprofits or projects headed by Feisal Abdul Rauf" are involved. They further explore the funding of the project's opponents.{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0910/41767.html#ixzz1zO46EMhc |title=Latest mosque issue: The money trail |date=September 5, 2010 |accessdate=July 1, 2012 |work=Politico |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710221815/http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0910/41767.html#ixzz1zO46EMhc |archivedate=July 10, 2012 |df= }} On the side of opponents to the project, fundings come from the Fairbrook Foundation, the umbrella organization of pro-Israël activists Aubrey & Joyce Chernick.L. Rozen, The Park51 money trail, Politico.com, September 4th, 2010. ===Abdul Rauf's views of the project=== [[Feisal Abdul Rauf|Abdul Rauf]], a Kuwaiti-American [[Sufi]] Muslim, was the chief proponent of the project until he was replaced in January 2011.{{cite news |author=Mohammed Al Shafey |url=http://aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=1&id=20990 |title=Controversy Rages in NYC over Planned Mosque Near Ground Zero |work=Asharq Al-Awsat |date=May 18, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820200028/http://www.aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=1 |archivedate=August 20, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news |author=Tom Topousis |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/manhattan/imam_terror_error_efmizkHuBUaVnfuQcrcabL#ixzz0rJTKPGE6 |title=Muslim Imam leading push to build a mosque near Ground Zero wavers on questions about Hamas as a terror group |work=New York Post |date=June 19, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cordobainitiative.org/?q=content/staff-bios#Imam%20Feisal%20Abdul%20Rauf|title=Staff Bios|date=July 31, 2007|publisher=The Cordoba Initiative|accessdate=August 3, 2010}} Some U.S. politicians and others voiced concerns about his views. Others, including ''The Economist'' have described him as "a well-meaning American cleric who has spent years trying to promote interfaith understanding". In an interview September 8, 2010 Abdul Rauf was asked if he would have done anything differently had he known the controversy would erupt. His answer: "If I knew this would happen, this would cause this kind of pain, I wouldn't have done it. My life has been devoted to peacemaking."{{cite news |url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1009/08/lkl.01.html |title=CNN.com Transcripts |publisher=CNN |date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100912001349/http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1009/08/lkl.01.html |archivedate=September 12, 2010 |df= }} The [[Stratfor]] [[2012 Stratfor email leak|email leaks]] posted on [[WikiLeaks]] identify Abdul Rauf as an "operational asset of the FBI", and speculate that the entire project may have been undertaken for political reasons.{{cite web |url=https://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/373982_re-ct-untangling-the-bizarre-cia-links-to-the-ground-zero.html |title=Re: [CT] Untangling the Bizarre CIA Links to the Ground Zero Mosque |publisher=[[WikiLeaks]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514120011/http://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/373982_re-ct-untangling-the-bizarre-cia-links-to-the-ground-zero.html|archive-date=May 14, 2013|dead-url=yes}} ===Effects on recruitment of radical Islamists=== Counterterrorism analysts have noted that the developing controversy over Park51 has provided a "recruitment opportunity" for radical Islamist groups. According to Evan Kohlmann, the senior partner in the New York-based security firm Flashpoint Global Partners, "[t]he reaction is, at least on the part of extremists, fairly gleeful – that America is playing into our hands, that America is revealing its ugly face, and that even if it doesn't further radicalize people in the Middle East, there's no doubt that it will radicalize a kind of a key constituency that al-Qaida and other extremists are seeking to covet{{Sic}}, seeking to court, which is the small number of homegrown extremists here in the United States".{{cite news |author=Gary Thomas |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Radical-Islamists-Try-to-Exploit-Islamophobia-101592048.html |title=Radical Islamists Try to Exploit Islamophobia |publisher=Voice of America |date=August 26, 2010 |accessdate=September 2, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830202224/http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Radical-Islamists-Try-to-Exploit-Islamophobia-101592048.html |archivedate=August 30, 2010 |df= }} ''Newsweek'' quotes a [[Taliban]] operative as explicitly connecting increased opposition to the project with increased support for the Taliban's cause. "By preventing this mosque from being built, America is doing us a big favor," the Taliban operative stated. "It's providing us with more recruits, donations, and popular support."{{cite news |author1=Sami Yousafzai |author2=Ron Moreau |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2010/08/30/taliban-using-mosque-controversy-to-recruit.html |title=The Taliban vs. the Mosque |work=Newsweek |date=August 30, 2010 |accessdate=September 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100902031055/http://www.newsweek.com/2010/08/30/taliban-using-mosque-controversy-to-recruit.html |archivedate=September 2, 2010 |df= }} ===Documentary=== In 2012, filmmaker David Osit produced a documentary about the Park51 controversy, specifically following the story through the experiences of developer Sharif El-Gamal. The film aired on [[Public Broadcasting System|PBS]] in the fall of 2013.{{cite news |url=http://www.itvs.org/films/building-babel |title='Building Babel – ITVS' |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140412062836/http://www.itvs.org/films/building-babel |archivedate=2014-04-12 |df= }} ==Public opinion== ===Polls=== [[File:Ground Zero Mosque Protesters 10.jpg|thumb|Opponents of Park51 protest on August 22, 2010.]] Polls showed that the majority of Americans, New York State residents, and New York City residents opposed building the center near Ground Zero, although a plurality or majority of Manhattanites supported construction. In July 2010, the majority of Americans were opposed to the Islamic center. |url=http://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/business/econ_survey_toplines/july_2010/toplines_mosque_july_19_20_2010 |title=Mosque – July 19–20, 2010 |publisher=Rasmussen Reports |date=July
